urn:contentItem:5PMW-4G81-JD34-V46Y-00000-00Climate Searing September The 'unprecedented' early season heat that baked Australia2017-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Climate Searing September The 'unprecedented' early season heat that baked AustraliaPeter Hannam

Last month's early-season bursts of heat sent temperatures of some parts of eastern Australia a full 16 degrees above average, shows new analysis by the Bureau of Meteorology.

In a Special Climate Statement examining two pulses of extreme warmth that seared large areas of inland Australia from Victoria to Queensland, the bureau identified the many national and statewide September records that tumbled.

During the first of those events, which affected NSW on September 23 and 24, all but three inland sites set record hot days for September.

On September 23 alone, 62 per cent of NSW had its hottest September day on record. A second heat burst set records in some northern parts of the state that had only been set a few days earlier.

"Hot, dry northerly winds ahead of [a] trough and cold front contributed to New South Wales, southern Queensland, and areas in neighbouring states experiencing unprecedented hot weather for this time of the year," the bureau said in its report.

While associated with large high pressure systems, the bureau noted global warming had pushed up background temperatures by about a degree over the past century for Australia and the planet as a whole, making the occurrence of such extreme events more likely.

"Studies undertaken by the bureau and other scientific institutions have shown that climate change has contributed to the severity and frequency of recent heat events, including spring warmth," it said.

The special report comes a day after new research showed Australian cities such as Melbourne and Sydney need to prepare for summer days when the temperature climbs to 50 degrees in decades to come - even if nations kept to Paris climate pledges to keep global warming to less than 2 degrees.

The bureau's report also noted that unusually dry conditions contributed to the recent abnormal heat. Both Sydney and NSW, for instance, posted their driest Septembers on record last month. Statewide, rainfall was just one-seventh of the usual amount for the month, extending a worsening dry spell that has lasted about three months.

Sydney, meanwhile, is on track to break the record for the most days in a row with less than 2 millimetres of rain.

The current record, spanning August-October 1989, stands at 64 days, a record likely to be match on Saturday and broken on Sunday, if current forecasts are correct, Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, said.

The recent significant heat emerged on September 21, with almost all the country recording above-average temperatures, the bureau said.

Australia as a whole recorded its warmest September day on record the following day, with a mean maximum temperature on 33.47 degrees. That was more than 6 degrees warmer than the September average, and eclipsed the previous September record of 33.39 degrees set on September 30, 1998. For NSW, though, the biggest heat spike came on September 23, with a large inland area reaching 16 degrees above average during the day. Apart from setting NSW's first September day with a maximum of 40 degrees, the statewide average maximum of 35.81 degrees smashed the previous record set in 2003 by 1.61 degrees.

An odd quirk in the heat was the range during the day, with some areas warming 30 degrees from their overnight minimums.

Canberra Airport, for instance, ranged from 1.3-30.2 degrees during the day, exceeding the previous record for any month of the year for the diurnal range.

Victoria posted its hottest September reading on September 23, with Mildura clocking a 37.7 reading.

For Queensland, the peak of the heat hit on September 27 when 36 per cent of the state had its hottest September day.

The state's mean maximum temperature that day reached was 37.79 degrees, eclipsing the previous September record of 37.43 degrees set in 1988.

The ongoing lack of rain in many regions has meant less cloud cover and available soil moisture to be evaporated, helping to drive daytime temperatures higher. There is some hope for better rainfall in the weeks ahead, including signs that the Pacific is tilting towards La Nina conditions. During La Nina events, eastern Australia tends to have above-average rainfall although cyclones also tend to increase in frequency in the Australian region.

Before the change, though, farmers and fire fighters are in for an anxious few weeks if not longer.

As the bureau's special report noted, dangerous fire conditions emerged during the recent heatwaves, including during the shorter second wave at the end of September. According to the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, values exceeded extreme levels at many sites across the country from September 22-27, the bureau said.

Most of the nation had fire danger index ratings above average at the end of September.

urn:contentItem:5K0Y-T641-JD3N-53DM-00000-00Conversations2016-06-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisFEEDBACKPg. 14Conversations

Thanks for co-operation I WANT to thank communities across Melbourne, particularly those in the northern suburbs, for your co-operation while 13 planned burns were completed during autumn.

The burns were successfully conducted by crews from Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Parks Victoria and the CFA.

Smoke from these burns was highly visible and some road closures were needed to ensure the safety of motorists and our fire fighters and we appreciate your understanding during those times.

Residents and business owners do provide valuable input into our decision making about bushfire management.

We thank those who've contributed and encourage more of you to get involved by talking with our forest fire management staff at your local department or Parks Victoria office, or by phoning us on 9210 9222.

BRYAN WELCH, DELWP Port Phillip region- assistant chief fire officer

Clarifying amendment REGARDING the letter from Colin, Nillumbik Council would like to make a clarification about the removal of dead vegetation and provide details about bushfire mitigation rights (Learn lessons of fires, Diamond Valley Leader, June 8).

While the original Amendment C101 documents stated that dead vegetation needed a permit to be removed, this condition is proposed to be amended. The submission council will make to the planning panel will propose that landowners can remove any dead vegetation from their property without a permit except for standing dead trees with a trunk diameter of 40cm or more and a height of 1.3m above ground level.

This is the same as the current ESO.

Amendment C101 has not changed people's bushfire mitigation rights. If a Bushfire Management Overlay applies, people can still clear trees up to 10m from their property and vegetation up to 50m from their property. There are more activities that people can do for bushfire mitigation that doesn't need a permit.

Visit council's website at nillumbik. vic.gov.au/c101bushfire for more details on the amendment.

If residents believe that a greater amount of vegetation management is required -beyond that allowed under the exemptions, then they can apply for a planning permit to do so, which will be assessed on its merits and with regard to CFA guidelines.

Nillumbik Council approved 98 per cent of all planning permits applications last year.

BRONNIE HATTAM, Nillumbik Mayor

Lower speed not a solution I HAVE been following the debate regarding the possible lowering of the speed limit on Chute St, Diamond Creek, with interest.

I use the crossing on Chute St about 6.15am every weekday and have done so for about the past 10 years. I firmly believe that lowering the speed limit on this stretch of road will not address the real problem.

Vehicles regularly go through these lights, even when I have the green man, but these vehicles are not speeding.

The driver has not failed to see the lights or feels he/she has to keep going because they are going too fast to stop.

I'm sure that they don't really want to hit a pedestrian, but they keep going and hope that whoever is waiting to cross will not step out in front of them.

The back routes through Diamond Creek are extremely busy with traffic trying to avoid Chute St and lowering the speed limit will only serve to exacerbate this.

Yes, if I am hit by a vehicle, I may be less severely injured because that vehicle is travelling at a slower speed, but I would prefer to be able to step on to the crossing confident that nothing is going to run into me.

The only way this problem will be solved is the installation of red light cameras, not by lowering the speed limit.SUSAN DUNNE, Diamond Creek

urn:contentItem:5PTH-T6H1-F0J6-J0NX-00000-00How 'unprecedented' early season heat scorched eastern Australia2017-10-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisHow 'unprecedented' early season heat scorched eastern AustraliaPeter Hannam

Last month's early-season bursts of heat sent temperatures of some parts of eastern Australia a full 16 degrees above average, new analysis by the Bureau of Meteorology shows.

In a Special Climate Statement examining two pulses of extreme warmth that seared large areas of inland Australia from Victoria to Queensland, the bureau identified the many national and statewide September records that tumbled.

During the first of those events, which affected NSW on September 23-24, all but three inland sites set record hot days for September.

On September 23 alone, 62 per cent of NSW had its hottest September day on record. A second heat burst set records in some northern parts of the state that had only been set a few days earlier.

"Hot, dry northerly winds ahead of [a] trough and cold front contributed to New South Wales, southern Queensland, and areas in neighbouring States experiencing unprecedented hot weather for this time of the year," the bureau said in its report.

While associated with large high pressure systems, the bureau noted global warming had pushed up background temperatures by about a degree over the past century for Australia and the planet as a whole, making the occurrence of such extreme events more likely.

"Studies undertaken by the Bureau and other scientific institutions have shown that climate change has contributed to the severity and frequency of recent heat events, including spring warmth," it said.

The special report comes a day after new research showed Australian cities such as Melbourne and Sydney need to prepare for summer days when the temperature climbs to 50 degrees in decades to come - even if nations kept to Paris climate pledges to keep global warming to less than 2 degrees.

Big dry impact The bureau's report also noted that unusually dry conditions contributed to the recent abnormal heat.

Both Sydney and NSW, for instance, posted their driest Septembers on record last month. Statewide, rainfall was just one-seventh of the usual amount for the month, extending a worsening dry spell that has lasted about three months.

Sydney, meanwhile, is on track to break the record for the most days in a row with less than 2 millimetres of rain.

The current record, spanning August-October 1989, stands at 64 days, a record likely to be match on Saturday and broken on Sunday, if current forecasts are correct, Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, said.

Hot times The recent significant heat emerged on September 21, with almost all the country recording above-average temperatures, the bureau said.

Australia as a whole recorded its warmest September day on record the following day, with a mean maximum temperature on 33.47 degrees. That was more than 6 degrees warmer than the September average, and eclipsed the previous September record of 33.39 degrees set on September 30, 1998.

For NSW, though, the biggest heat spike came on September 23, with a large inland area reaching 16 degrees above average during the day. (See chart below.)

Apart from setting NSW's first September day with a maximum of 40 degrees, the statewide average maximum of 35.81 degrees smashed the previous record set in 2003 by 1.61 degrees.

An odd quirk in the heat was the range during the day, with some areas warming 30 degrees from their overnight minimums.

Canberra Airport, for instance, ranged from 1.3-30.2 degrees during the day day, exceeding the previous record for any month of the year for the diurnal range.

Victoria posted its hottest September reading on September 23, with Mildura clocking a 37.7 reading.

For Queensland, the peak of the heat hit on September 27 when 36 per cent of the state had its hottest September day.

The state's mean maximum temperature that day reached was 37.79 degrees, eclipsing the previous September record of 37.43 degrees set in 1988.

Drought widens The ongoing lack of rain in many regions has meant less cloud cover and available soil moisture to be evaporated, helping to drive daytime temperatures higher.

The bureau's latest drought statement, out on Wednesday, showed rainfall deficiencies are intensifying in inland regions, particularly in NSW. (See bureau chart below.)

There is some hope for better rainfall in the weeks ahead, including signs that the Pacific is tilting towards La Nina conditions.

During La Nina events, eastern Australia tends to have above-average rainfall although cyclones also tend to increase in frequency in the Australian region.

Before the change, though, farmers and fire fighters are in for an anxious few weeks if not longer.

As the bureau's special report noted, dangerous fire conditions emerged during the recent heatwaves, including during the shorter second wave at the end of September.

According to the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, values exceeded extreme levels at many sites across the country from September 22-27, the bureau said.

As the map below shows, most of the nation had fire danger index ratings very much above average at the end of September.

urn:contentItem:56MB-6761-JD34-V3MF-00000-00Severe Weather Season2012-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 5Severe Weather SeasonSIMON CHAMBERLAIN

THE outlook for the weather season from October to April carries an alarming prognosis for emergency services, according to The Weather Channel

Yesterday it was forecasting an almost apocalyptic picture with an increase in bushfires, temperature, heatwaves and tropical cyclones this summer.

The channel's chief meteorologist Dick Whitaker said Melbourne, Canberra and Adelaide were at increased risk of heatwaves this season compared to 2011/12, thanks to the fusion of the weak El Nino and warm Indian Ocean.

"Heatwaves along the east coast are extremely rare with Sydney, Brisbane and Hobart averaging less than one heatwave every 10 years," he said.

"It is therefore with much confidence we predict zero heatwaves for those capitals.

"While Perth is also set for above-average temperatures this season, we expect less heatwaves than 2011/2012 which was abnormally hot, the fourth hottest on record for summer maximums," Mr Whitaker said.

Like temperatures, heatwaves in Australia are also linked to the shifting pattern of sea surface temperatures through the Pacific and Indian Oceans. The Weather Channel defines heatwaves using the 5/5 rule - five consecutive days where the maximum temperature equals or exceeds five degrees above the average.

"There is heightened risk of bushfires this season for most of the country compared to the 2010/11 and 2011/12 seasons," Mr Whitaker said.

"Grassland areas of inland New South Wales and southern inland Queensland are most at risk, thanks to the heavy rainfall of the past two La Nina years which has resulted in heavy vegetation growth," he said.

During the severe weather season Australia encounters two types of bushfire; grass fire and forest fire.The potential for grass fires is dependent on the previous severe weather seasons rainfall. The risk of forest fires can increase as a result of long hot, dry periods followed by days with extreme heat, strong winds and low humidity.

Hot northerly winds ahead of a south-west change is the key weather pattern to watch and has been the weather setup behind most of Australia's most devastating forest fires.

While associated with large high pressure systems, the bureau noted global warming had pushed up background temperatures by about a degree over the past century for Australia and the planet as a whole, making the occurrence of such extreme events more likely.

"Studies undertaken by the Bureau and other scientific institutions have shown that climate change has contributed to the severity and frequency of recent heat events, including spring warmth," it said.

The special report comes a day after new research showed Australian cities such as Melbourne and Sydney need to prepare for summer days when the temperature climbs to 50 degrees in decades to come - even if nations kept to Paris climate pledges to keep global warming to less than 2 degrees.

Big dry impact The bureau's report also noted that unusually dry conditions contributed to the recent abnormal heat.

Both Sydney and NSW, for instance, posted their driest Septembers on record last month. Statewide, rainfall was just one-seventh of the usual amount for the month, extending a worsening dry spell that has lasted about three months.

Sydney, meanwhile, is on track to break the record for the most days in a row with less than 2 millimetres of rain.

The current record, spanning August-October 1989, stands at 64 days, a record likely to be match on Saturday and broken on Sunday, if current forecasts are correct, Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, said.

Hot times The recent significant heat emerged on September 21, with almost all the country recording above-average temperatures, the bureau said.

Australia as a whole recorded its warmest September day on record the following day, with a mean maximum temperature on 33.47 degrees. That was more than 6 degrees warmer than the September average, and eclipsed the previous September record of 33.39 degrees set on September 30, 1998.

For NSW, though, the biggest heat spike came on September 23, with a large inland area reaching 16 degrees above average during the day. (See chart below.)

Apart from setting NSW's first September day with a maximum of 40 degrees, the statewide average maximum of 35.81 degrees smashed the previous record set in 2003 by 1.61 degrees.

An odd quirk in the heat was the range during the day, with some areas warming 30 degrees from their overnight minimums.

Canberra Airport, for instance, ranged from 1.3-30.2 degrees during the day day, exceeding the previous record for any month of the year for the diurnal range.

Victoria posted its hottest September reading on September 23, with Mildura clocking a 37.7 reading.

For Queensland, the peak of the heat hit on September 27 when 36 per cent of the state had its hottest September day.

The state's mean maximum temperature that day reached was 37.79 degrees, eclipsing the previous September record of 37.43 degrees set in 1988.

Drought widens The ongoing lack of rain in many regions has meant less cloud cover and available soil moisture to be evaporated, helping to drive daytime temperatures higher.

The bureau's latest drought statement, out on Wednesday, showed rainfall deficiencies are intensifying in inland regions, particularly in NSW. (See bureau chart below.)

There is some hope for better rainfall in the weeks ahead, including signs that the Pacific is tilting towards La Nina conditions.

During La Nina events, eastern Australia tends to have above-average rainfall although cyclones also tend to increase in frequency in the Australian region.

Before the change, though, farmers and fire fighters are in for an anxious few weeks if not longer.

As the bureau's special report noted, dangerous fire conditions emerged during the recent heatwaves, including during the shorter second wave at the end of September.

According to the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, values exceeded extreme levels at many sites across the country from September 22-27, the bureau said.

As the map below shows, most of the nation had fire danger index ratings very much above average at the end of September.

urn:contentItem:7WHG-GRC0-Y9Y8-S0B8-00000-00Cooler conditions aid NSW firefighters2009-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisCooler conditions aid NSW firefighters

The New South Wales Rural Fire Service says mild weather has helped firefighters to stay on top of a fire burning near Ulladulla on the state's south coast.

About 150 volunteer firefighters and six helicopters have been battling the fire between Burrill Lake and Lake Tabourie, which has burnt out nearly 3,000 hectares of bushland and forest.

Fire crews are constructing containment lines around the fire and Matthew Schroder from the Rural Fire Service says firefighters plan to carry out backburning operations overnight.

"Crews will be backburning off Woodburn Road ... to the west of the fire and they hope that by doing this they can try and bring this fire under control," he said.

He says no properties are under direct threat from the fire but residents should still be vigilant in monitoring the fire situation.

The backburning was placed on hold earlier today due to a flare-up near Lake Tabourie.

There is also a bushfire continuing to burn around Mount Dromedary in the Eurobodalla area.

Fire crews today directly attacked the fire front and are planning backburning operations to the south-east of the blaze.

Meanwhile, a grassfire in Sydney's south-west has created heavy traffic on the Hume Highway.

A northbound lane on the highway has been reopened, as crews mop up after the blaze.

A bushfire is also burning in rugged terrain at nearby Macquarie Fields but it is not threatening any properties.

urn:contentItem:56M6-XB91-F0JP-W34H-00000-00Firebug likely as smoke clears2012-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Firebug likely as smoke clearsNIKKI TODD

AUTHORITIES are investigating the possibility of an arsonist on the Tweed Coast after four blazes in the last week including a major bushfire at Kings Forest.

More than 40 firefighters from the Rural Fire Service and Fire and Rescue NSW were called to tackle a major bushfire that burned through 95ha of land at Kings Forest and Cudgen Nature Reserve last Friday.

Firefighters were kept busy across the weekend after another blaze broke out on the eastern side of Tweed Coast Road near Salt on Saturday and another at Fingal Head on Sunday afternoon.

The fires followed a smaller blaze in the dunes at Cabarita earlier in the week with fire investigators now considering all may have been deliberately lit.

RFS Far North Coast team manager Superintendent David Cook said an investigation involving fire authorities and police had begun.

``It appears to be suspicious, that is all I can say at this stage - there is no other possible reason why the fire was caused,'' Supt Cook said.

Supt Cook said he had taken the first call about the Kings Forest fire too early for the sun to have played a role in the blaze.

``I got the first call to it at 5.30 on Friday morning,'' he said.

``Earlier in the week we had another fire in the dunes down at Cabarita that started for no apparent reason as well.''

Tweed Byron police crime manager Acting Inspector Saul Wiseman said a criminal detective had been assigned to investigate the fires but it was still too early to make a call on whether they were the act of an arsonist or not.

``We haven't any indication at the moment as to what has caused this fire,'' he said.

``To say there has been some firebugs may be early days yet.''

Insp Wiseman said the case would be referred to Strike Force Tronto, an ongoing taskforce investigating deliberately-lit bushfires in NSW.

A NSW Parks and Wildlife spokesman said no evidence had been found of injured wildlife from the fire at Cudgen Paddock.

Call crime stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5H7D-8VD1-JD34-V3RJ-00000-00New system to spot areas most at fire risk2015-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSNew system to spot areas most at fire riskPeter Hannam

Communities and firefighters could soon receive real-time warnings of risks from bushfires down to a matter of kilometres, according to a new model being tested this fire season.

As fire crews across south-east Australiapreparefor an unusually active bushfire season amid an abnormally warm spring and an intensifying El Nino, researchers hope technological advances will soon give communities real-time information on the probabilityof fire threats down to a resolution ofa few kilometres.

"People want to know: It's a fire danger, but a fire danger to what?" saysRossBradstock, director of the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong, and one of the developers of the new model.

"It incorporates the probability of a fire starting and spreading, based on the fuel and the terrain, and it reaching property," ProfessorBradstocksaid."The warning system can be tailored to parts of towns or even suburbs."

The current warning system, modified after the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria to include a "catastrophic" threat level, has been based on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index first developed in the 1960s. That method, however, is based only on weather, such as temperature, relative humidity and wind speed.

The variables includedin the National Fire Danger Rating System Probabilistic Framework range from fuel load and its type, the nature of the terrain and the housing density in a particular region.

A prototype was tested in the Sydney region including the Blue Mountains and an areaeast of Melbourne stretching from the Dandenong Ranges to Phillip Island. The model will be tested by fire authoritiesin NSW this fire season, with thefindingsto date publishedby the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre.

"You can have a region with a lower fire rating but have a particular location with a higher risk," Trent Penman, a bushfire behaviour specialist at the University of Melbourne, and anotherdeveloper of the new model. "For people in those properties to know they are at higher risk would be beneficial for their preparations."

Victoria and NSW are divided into large fire districts, and the new model potentially could provide "fine grained" warnings of potential property loss down to five kilometres or less.

'National priority'

Richard Thornton, chief executive of theBushfire and Natural Hazards CRC, said the existing fire danger rating system had been largely unchanged since the 1960s.

"A new fire danger rating system is a national priority and it is crucial that it is underpinned by the best science available," Dr Thornton said.

"This is about improving public safety and using science to more accurately predict and communicate bushfire risk," he said. The work is being coordinated by the federalAttorney-General's Department and involvesstate and territory emergency services, the Bureau of Meteorology, CSIRO, and several universities.

Kevin Tolhurst,an associate professor in fire ecology at theUniversity of Melbourne, said the probabilistic model was one of several being considered by fire authorities.

The new system could take "two or three years before it is routine", and a key issue will be how the information is communicated to the public, particularly if warnings becomemuch more detailed.

While avoiding confusion will be a challenge, the more specific warning may also result in greater involvement from residents.

"With fire management, you want individuals to respond to what is a community problem," Professor Tolhurst said.

urn:contentItem:56CW-X9B1-JD3N-5537-00000-00Spending cuts blamed for fuelling wildfires2012-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 10Spending cuts blamed for fuelling wildfiresROGER BOYES

AS fierce flames licked around some of Europe's top holiday destinations angry residents have blamed austerity cuts for reducing the efficiency of firefighting services.

Stoked by the high temperatures, but aggravated by a dry winter, wood and bushland fires have been sweeping southern and eastern Europe. The Brussels-based European Forest Fire Information System warns that the fire risk remains high, especially along the western Mediterranean. Many of the countries at risk are those suffering public spending cutbacks that have eaten into local rescue service budgets.

Worst hit has been Spain, where 140,000ha of woodland have been destroyed in Catalonia, in the Cabaneros National Park in the centre of the country and in the Donana National Park in the southwest.

Spanish Environment Minister Miguel Arias Canete emphasised yesterday that the national firefighting budget was the one item that had not been sliced from his budget in the tough public spending cuts. But, he added, it was up to regional governments how they allocated their resources and he could not be held responsible for their decisions. ``Each region decides freely where it will make its cuts,'' he said. ``And each region will now have to analyse whether its fire precaution measures are sufficient.''

Cold comfort in a spectacularly hot season, in particular on the Canary Islands where residents are -- in between evacuating their homes -- already demonstrating against the local administration for trying to balance the budget by sacking firefighters. Asier Antona, secretary-general of the Partido Popular (People's Party) on the Canaries, accused the governor of the islands, Casimiro Curbelo, of being a ``political pyromaniac''.

Because of the cuts there were insufficient helicopters to deal with the blaze as it swept through the ancient, thickset woodland. Mr Curbelo had to plead with the national government for six additional fire-extinguishing helicopters and had to make do with two borrowed from Morocco.

About a half-dozen firefighters have died in southern Europe. One died in Portugal last week in Figueiro dos Vinhos.

urn:contentItem:51C9-9T11-JC0X-K058-00000-00SA:Fewer catastrophic fire days for SA2010-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSA:Fewer catastrophic fire days for SAADELAIDE Nov 1

  Changes have been made to the threshold for declaring catastrophic fire risk conditions across South Australia this summer.
   The Country Fire Service (CFS) and the South Australian government on Monday launched the fire risk season, warning winter's good rainfall meant fuel loads would be high in many areas.


   Last summer five catastrophic days were declared in SA, but changes for the new season would result in fewer under similar conditions.
   CFS deputy chief officer Andrew Lawson said the criteria for declaring a catastrophic day was set too low.
   "Given the same weather conditions as last year, we should see a reduction in the number of catastrophic warnings issued this year," he told reporters.
   "We felt that the conditions didn't actually warrant the actual catastrophic warnings in a number of our districts last year, so the criteria was just set a little low for the fuel load and the vegetation types we have in South Australia."
   Mr Lawson said the changes would also allow for a distinction between the risk posed by a grass fire as opposed to those of a forest fire.
   "What we have introduced is a more accurate reflection on the actual risk which is being posed locally," he said.
   Emergency Services Minister Michael Wright said anyone living in a bushfire risk area should ensure they had a bushfire survival plan in place, at least 20 metres of defendable ground around their home and adequate fire fighting equipment and protective clothing.
   While assistant commissioner Bryan Fahy said police would again target suspicious behaviour in bushfire areas through Operation Nomad.
   Last summer 42 people were arrested and almost 200 fines were issued for fire-related incidents.

urn:contentItem:5SWB-RXC1-JD34-V2G9-00000-00Burning questions for Europe2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 12Burning questions for EuropeNick Miller

Climate change may be fuelling the record fires this summer, writes Nick Miller.

London: As the official death toll from Greece's wildfires mounted yesterday, it became clear this was a national tragedy of a kind awfully familiar to Australians.

Horrific stories emerged as rescue workers made gruesome discoveries, such as the group of 26 men, women and children who perished while huddled together, trapped between the fire front and a sheer cliff. The death toll stood at 79 last night.

Many more survived by the skin of their teeth - fleeing into the sea as the fires overtook their holiday houses. It is the peak holiday period for locals as well as tourists. Fishing and coastguard vessels patrolled the coast, plucking people out of the water to safety.

Strong, unpredictable winds fanned and spread flames that killed people in their homes and in some of the hundreds, perhaps thousands, of cars used to try to flee but were lost in smoke and gridlock.

"Everything happened in seconds," Andreaas Passios, who lives in the devastated town of Mati, told the Times. "I grabbed a beach towel. It saved my life. I soaked it, grabbed my wife and we ran to the sea."

He and his wife stayed by the sea for two hours watching the inferno. "It was unbelievable. Gas canisters were exploding, burning pine cones were flying everywhere."

The fire is the latest, and most tragic, result of a heatwave that has baked Europe this summer, setting temperature records and starting fires from Norway to Spain.

Sweden has lost an estimated 30,000 hectares of forest in wildfires across the country, which were still burning yesterday - though the number of fires had dropped from 80 last week to about 20.

The area is more than 10 times the average annual area burnt by fire in a typical Swedish summer.

Forests are vital to the Swedish economy and the country has called for help in fighting the fires. Summer temperatures typically hit the low 20s. The current 30+ degree heatwave is rare and authorities lack the resources to tackle big fires.

A week ago, Italy sent two firefighting planes to help the Swedes, and other countries including Poland, Portugal and France also lent volunteers and equipment.

The response is being co-ordinated by the European Union's Civil Protection and Emergency Response centre, which helps share the load during disasters.

The same group has now mobilised to help Greece, while Australia has offered to assist the recovery effort.

"As a country that has one of the largest expatriate populations of Greek nationals of anywhere around the world, we deeply empathise with those who are caught up in these tragic fires in Greece," Treasurer Scott Morrison said yesterday.

"There will be many Australians I'm sure who have family members that may be affected."

Fires have also ravaged woods and grassland in northern Finland near the Russian border, Latvia has lost more than 800 hectares in fires that have raged for almost a week, and a Norwegian firefighter died last week trying to contain a wildfire.

Last year, 66 people died from wildfires in Portugal - its biggest loss of lives. Also last year, an EU report predicted new "forest fire danger extremes" due to climate change in Europe.

Scientific modelling has shown the south and south-eastern parts of Europe would be worst hit. And these trends would continue to get worse - and extend northwards.

About a third of Europe - 215 million hectares - is covered by forest. In 2010, wildfires damaged about half a million hectares but this number is expected to rise dramatically. Last year, the burnt area in Portugal, Spain and Italy alone was almost double that.

The report from the EU's science service, the Joint Research Centre, found that climate change would reduce the protective effect of the Alps, which creates an area of high moisture guarding Europe's heart.

Down by the sea, lower rainfall and higher temperatures would dry forests into summer tinderboxes.

"It is clear that the danger of forest fires driven by weather increases with climate change around the Mediterranean," the report found.

The report had expected relatively little change in weather-driven fire danger across northern Europe due to climate change.

Another report from the European Environment Agency said Mediterranean countries were already seeing more heat extremes, reduced rainfall and river flows, and resulting severe droughts, lower crop yields, forest fires and heatwave deaths.

In the north of the continent, the temperature rise will be even bigger than the global average, with a decrease in snow and ice cover, an increase in crop yields and decrease in heating costs, but increasing risk of damage from winter storms.

In central and eastern Europe, there will be less summer rain and a bigger risk of forest fires. In the mountains, there will be less skiing and more species extinction.

"[These heatwaves are] exactly the kind of event we are expecting to see," said Professor Corinne Le Quere, director of the climate change research team at the University of East Anglia.

"In a warmer climate, we expect more extreme events; we expect extreme heatwaves to be hotter and last longer."

However, fire is "a whole different beast" and harder to predict, Le Quere said. Wildfires have a range of causes and only some are linked to climate change: for example heat drying out forests, and more lightning starting fires.

Some wildfires, such as those two years ago in Canada, have been examined and the link to climate change is "very clear", she said.

She expects scientists to closely examine the fires in Sweden this year, to see if there can be an attribution to climate change. If so, this may confound models that had predicted no increase in fires due to a predicted increase in rainfall.

"We really need to think about how do we tackle climate change in a way that protects us and reduces risk," she said.

Research estimated that without mitigation and adaptation, there would be 200,000 heat-related deaths per year in Europe by 2100..

'We expect more extreme events.' Professor Corinne Le Quere

urn:contentItem:5SWB-RXC1-JD34-V2BP-00000-00Burning questions for Europe2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 14Burning questions for EuropeNick Miller

Climate change may be fuelling the record fires this summer, writes Nick Miller.

London: As the official death toll from Greece's wildfires mounted yesterday, it became clear this was a national tragedy of a kind awfully familiar to Australians.

Horrific stories emerged as rescue workers made gruesome discoveries, such as the group of 26 men, women and children who perished while huddled together, trapped between the fire front and a sheer cliff. The death toll stood at 79 last night.

Many more survived by the skin of their teeth - fleeing into the sea as the fires overtook their holiday houses. It is the peak holiday period for locals as well as tourists. Fishing and coastguard vessels patrolled the coast, plucking people out of the water to safety.

Strong, unpredictable winds fanned and spread flames that killed people in their homes and in some of the hundreds, perhaps thousands, of cars used to try to flee but were lost in smoke and gridlock.

"Everything happened in seconds," Andreaas Passios, who lives in the devastated town of Mati, told the Times. "I grabbed a beach towel. It saved my life. I soaked it, grabbed my wife and we ran to the sea."

He and his wife stayed by the sea for two hours watching the inferno. "It was unbelievable. Gas canisters were exploding, burning pine cones were flying everywhere."

The fire is the latest, and most tragic, result of a heatwave that has baked Europe this summer, setting temperature records and starting fires from Norway to Spain.

Sweden has lost an estimated 30,000 hectares of forest in wildfires across the country, which were still burning yesterday - though the number of fires had dropped from 80 last week to about 20.

The area is more than 10 times the average annual area burnt by fire in a typical Swedish summer.

Forests are vital to the Swedish economy and the country has called for help in fighting the fires. Summer temperatures typically hit the low 20s. The current 30+ degree heatwave is rare and authorities lack the resources to tackle big fires.

A week ago, Italy sent two firefighting planes to help the Swedes, and other countries including Poland, Portugal and France also lent volunteers and equipment.

The response is being co-ordinated by the European Union's Civil Protection and Emergency Response centre, which helps share the load during disasters.

The same group has now mobilised to help Greece, while Australia has offered to assist the recovery effort.

"As a country that has one of the largest expatriate populations of Greek nationals of anywhere around the world, we deeply empathise with those who are caught up in these tragic fires in Greece," Treasurer Scott Morrison said yesterday.

"There will be many Australians I'm sure who have family members that may be affected."

Fires have also ravaged woods and grassland in northern Finland near the Russian border, Latvia has lost more than 800 hectares in fires that have raged for almost a week, and a Norwegian firefighter died last week trying to contain a wildfire.

Last year, 66 people died from wildfires in Portugal - its biggest loss of lives. Also last year, an EU report predicted new "forest fire danger extremes" due to climate change in Europe.

Scientific modelling has shown the south and south-eastern parts of Europe would be worst hit. And these trends would continue to get worse - and extend northwards.

About a third of Europe - 215 million hectares - is covered by forest. In 2010, wildfires damaged about half a million hectares but this number is expected to rise dramatically. Last year, the burnt area in Portugal, Spain and Italy alone was almost double that.

The report from the EU's science service, the Joint Research Centre, found that climate change would reduce the protective effect of the Alps, which creates an area of high moisture guarding Europe's heart.

Down by the sea, lower rainfall and higher temperatures would dry forests into summer tinderboxes.

"It is clear that the danger of forest fires driven by weather increases with climate change around the Mediterranean," the report found.

The report had expected relatively little change in weather-driven fire danger across northern Europe due to climate change.

Another report from the European Environment Agency said Mediterranean countries were already seeing more heat extremes, reduced rainfall and river flows, and resulting severe droughts, lower crop yields, forest fires and heatwave deaths.

In the north of the continent, the temperature rise will be even bigger than the global average, with a decrease in snow and ice cover, an increase in crop yields and decrease in heating costs, but increasing risk of damage from winter storms.

In central and eastern Europe, there will be less summer rain and a bigger risk of forest fires. In the mountains, there will be less skiing and more species extinction.

"[These heatwaves are] exactly the kind of event we are expecting to see," said Professor Corinne Le Quere, director of the climate change research team at the University of East Anglia.

"In a warmer climate, we expect more extreme events; we expect extreme heatwaves to be hotter and last longer."

However, fire is "a whole different beast" and harder to predict, Le Quere said. Wildfires have a range of causes and only some are linked to climate change: for example heat drying out forests, and more lightning starting fires.

Some wildfires, such as those two years ago in Canada, have been examined and the link to climate change is "very clear", she said.

She expects scientists to closely examine the fires in Sweden this year, to see if there can be an attribution to climate change. If so, this may confound models that had predicted no increase in fires due to a predicted increase in rainfall.

"We really need to think about how do we tackle climate change in a way that protects us and reduces risk," she said.

Research estimated that without mitigation and adaptation, there would be 200,000 heat-related deaths per year in Europe by 2100..

urn:contentItem:56BT-F6M1-F12F-F4G1-00000-00QUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE REMINDS NORTH COAST REGION RESIDENTS TO BE CAUTIOUS AND VIGILANT WITH EXPECTED HEIGHTENED FIRE DANGER RATING2012-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisQUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE REMINDS NORTH COAST REGION RESIDENTS TO BE CAUTIOUS AND VIGILANT WITH EXPECTED HEIGHTENED FIRE DANGER RATING

BRISBANE, Queensland, Aug. 16 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) is reminding North Coast Region residents to be cautious and vigilant with a heightened fire danger rating expected in the coming days.

QFRS North Coast Regional Manager Rural Operations Peter Hollier said a high to very high forest fire danger ratings were forecast for today and tomorrow and measures were being taken by firefighters to prepare for potential vegetation fires.

"We are expecting strong winds which will bring with them very dry conditions," he said.

"Residents in the region, particularly in the Wide Bay and Kingaroy areas, should be vigilant."

Mr Hollier encouraged persons planning on conducting hazard reduction burns to re-evaluate their plans and take extra precautions.

"Anyone considering conducting hazard reduction burns should speak directly with their fire warden first," he said.

"Landowners who have conducted hazard reduction burns recently are strongly encouraged to take steps to ensure their fire has been properly extinguished or to make sure the residual fire is contained so that it will not escape with the forecast winds in the coming days."

Mr Hollier said firefighters were already starting to see fire activity around the region, which made it crucial for residents to make sure they were doing all they could to prepare their homes and properties.

"If they haven't done so already, I urge residents to finalise preparing their property and visit the Rural Fire Service website to download a bushfire survival plan so that no one is caught off guard," he said.

"We are also asking people to ensure they are not throwing cigarette butts out of car windows and to be careful when operating machinery in dry grassed areas."

More information about how to prepare for bushfire season can be found at www.ruralfire.qld.gov.au For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:4N09-G1K0-TX5M-436B-00000-00Groups in bid2007-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Groups in bidto save koalas

HOMELESS and injured koalas have been rescued from raging bushfires in south-west Victoria and transferred to Healesville Sanctuary.

Groups have banded together to help rescue about 150 koalas from the Framlingham Forest fire, about 25km north-east of Warrnambool.

Ten of those koalas have a new home at the Wildlife Health Centre at the sanctuary for intensive veterinary care and rehabilitation.

To save the koalas, the CFA and Department of Sustainability and Environment have joined forces with Help For Wildlife, Wildlife Victoria, the Australian Koala Foundation and Wildlife Rescue and Information Network.

DSE wildlife officer Stan Williams said it was fantastic to see the organisations working together to rescue the animals.

Mr Williams said the koalas had no food and trees left in the burnt 1075ha forest.

Tree climbers are removing the koalas because the plants are too tall.

''The focus now is to plan ahead as to where to release the koalas because the Framlingham Forest won't be able to support any for at least two years,'' Mr Williams said.

Healesville Sanctuary's staff are providing specialised care and advice for vets and wildlife carers across Australia, as fires sweep across drought-stricken bush areas.

urn:contentItem:5H2Y-DVT1-DXMH-114P-00000-00Australian company investigated over Indonesian fires2015-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisAustralian company investigated over Indonesian firesJewel Topsfield

Indonesia rules out evacuations in forest fire areas   Troops battle fires as thousands fall ill in Malaysia, Singapore   Singapore and Malaysia urged to share responsibility for fires   Asian haze set to become worst on record

Jakarta: An Australian company is being investigated by Indonesian police over a fire on a palm oil plantation in Borneo as the republic tries to crack down on companies responsible for the haze choking the region.

Kayung Agro Lestari, which has a palm oil plantation in Ketapang regency in West Kalimantan, is one of 42 companies being investigated over the forest fires.

The slash-and-burn technique of land clearing used by some palm oil and timber plantations is commonly blamed for starting the fires, which have created dangerous levels of air pollution in parts of Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore.

The fires dog the region every year but have been exacerbated this year by El Nino and protracted drought in parts of Indonesia.

Malaysia has ordered all schools to close for two days because of the thick smog and the first night of finals at swimming's World Cup in Singapore was cancelled on Saturday.

Indonesian police told reporters that as of October 1 they were investigating 232 cases of forest and plantation fires. Forty-two cases involve corporations, including two foreign investment companies - Kayung Agro Lestari (PT KAL) from Australia and PT ASP from China.

West Kalimantan police spokesperson Arianto told Fairfax Media there was fire in Kayung Agro Lestari's concession.

"Therefore we are investigating the company," he said. "We have called witnesses from the local community, from the company itself and experts. We don't have any conclusions at the moment because the investigation is still ongoing."

In a statement late last month, Kayung Agro Lestari said that as of September 22, 356 hectares on its 17,998 concession had caught fire. "These fires were caused by windborne sparks from fires outside our plantation area," it said. "All of these fires have been put out by our team."

The statement said Kalimantan was facing an extremely dry climate and high winds. "Together they make the plantation vulnerable to outbreaks of fire, especially from wind-borne sparks originating in fires outside our plantation."

Kayung Agro Lestari said it was in daily coordination with the police and regional disaster management in fighting the fires and investigating their causes.

"The most serious outbreak PT KAL has witnessed was a fire affecting a large area of land just beside our plantation. Our team has worked together with the local authorities and communities to contain the fire. We also recorded that five orangutan fled from the fire and moved into our conservation area. As far as we can determine they are unharmed."

Rising global demand for palm oil, which is widely used in food and cosmetics, has led to the clearing of forests in Indonesian national parks, high levels of greenhouse gas emissions and the destruction of the habitat of endangered species including the Sumatran orangutan and tiger.

Kayung Agro Lestari is a subsidiary of PT Austindo Nusantara Jaya Agri, which is a member of the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil.

Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil certification is an assurance to buyers of palm oil products that the standard of production is sustainable.

With Amilia Rosa

urn:contentItem:5XH2-P281-F0J6-J05X-00000-00LETTERS2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 24LETTERS

The west deserves better

The non-response from Victoria's Health Minister to the urgent need for a hospital in Melton is another example of the west being neglected. Neither side of politics is prepared to commit to funding much-needed health services there. The vital new Footscray Hospital is being built closer to the CBD - i.e., further away from the population it is meant to service.

Werribee Mercy Hospital can only cater for 40 per cent of our current population of 270,000, which is expected to double in the next 20 years. We have no plastic surgery, no colposcopy, and huge waiting lists for orthopaedics and colonoscopies. Women are driving past Werribee Hospital to have babies at Sunshine because of capacity issues. There is not even funding to plan for an expansion.

Instead what the west gets are community "hospitals" which are basically day centres. Interestingly, both Melton and Werribee bucked the statewide trend at the 2018 state election and recorded 7 per cent swings against the government. The underfunding of health services in the western suburbs is an embarrassment to both sides of politics. We deserve much better.

Dr Joe Garra, Werribee South

The right to work on site

It is disturbing that the Construction, Forestry, Maritime, Mining and Energy Union was fined $50,500 for stopping work over demands for a separate toilet for a female worker and a bigger shed for 16 workers (The Age, 14/11). As a young female engineer in the 1980s, at times I had to share a male bathroom on site. It was truly horrible, particularly as the arrangements made for me to use the bathroom increased the hostility of some male workers towards having women on site.

Fortunately we got a female bathroom. This meant that more women felt safe enough to work on site. Female toilets are a vital measure in improving women's participation in non-traditional areas. It was a no-brainer 30 years ago, but we have clearly gone backwards. Thank goodness for strong unions.Andrea Bunting,

Brunswick

What's good for the goose

The chief executive of the Minerals Council of Australia says the proposed demerit system for unions "provides an incentive to make sure union officials are behaving well" (The Age, 11/11). In which case the same should apply to executive and board members of mining companies that over-extract water, issue hazardous waste, cause air pollution, pollute waterways and fail to restore abandoned mine sites.

Jane Touzeau, Elwood

Police self-protection?

If l were a police officer confronted with a group of rowdy activists, and I felt the need to whack them with my truncheon or spray them with pepper spray or push them over, I would turn off my body-worn camera first or delete the footage afterwards (The Age, 12/11). Better to face a reprimand than a charge of assault.

Ben Laycock, Barkers Creek

Let down by my Labor

Thank you, Nick Legge - "Devil in detail of Andrews' logging announcement" (Comment, 13/11). When I heard that the Premier had halted the felling of old-growth trees in Victoria, I applauded. Now I see that the felling was limited and grandfather trees in the Toolangi forest and Rubicon are still open to rampant destruction in the next five years.

Of course, the "forestry industry" will ramp up its efforts to "compensate" for the decision so that there will be no trees left to seed their future. What a disappointment. I assume it has been made as a compromise between loggers' interests and those of the environmental movement to protect votes. Can't the Premier see that this compromise fails both ways? As a lifetime ALP voter, I now realise my loyalty has been terribly misguided.Martin Shaw,

Mirboo North

Liberals' crocodile tears

So the Victorian Liberals are concerned about the mental health of timber workers (The Age, 14/11). Where were their concerns when their federal counterparts closed the auto industry, putting at least 10 times as many people out of work?Geoff Mulhall, Caulfield

The forgotten birds

The peregrine falcons nesting above Collins Street have been a hit with the public (Comment, 11/11) with many thousands of people watching the livestream.

If duck-cams were on our wetlands, they would show waterbirds going about their lives - feeding, swimming, diving. But if the cameras streamed from March until June, people would see the carnage of duck shooting for themselves. There would be an outcry. All birds are equal but it seems that some birds are more equal than others.Vikki Addicott,

Preston

Ready and happy to assist

I suggest the ABC gets its act together and takes on the non-commercial broadcast rights for the 2020 Olympic Games in quick time. The broadcast of the games is at the very heart of what the ABC is supposed to be about. If budgetary constraints are really an issue, then I make my services available to the managing director. I guarantee I will be able to identify savings that are more than sufficient to finance the costs of carrying the Tokyo Games and the one after that.Garry Ringwood,

Kew

State-wide cycling issues

The lack of a unified cycling network, as raised by David Joyce in relation to Melbourne (Letters, 14/11), applies equally in country towns. Here in Port Fairy - which should be a cycling-friendly town with its wide, flat roads - we also have disappearing bike lanes, lack of signage, unsafe road edges and dangerous intersections.

It is well documented that the major barrier to cycling participation is a perceived lack of safety on the roads. Even in a small town like ours, these problems appear to be significant deterrents to cycling by old and young alike.Paul Bucci,

Port Fairy Bicycling Action Group

Protecting the residents

The fires in New South Wales and Queensland are an ominous portent of the threat facing Victoria. It is interesting, therefore, to read the most recent edition of the Indigo Shire Council newsletter. It advises that landowners must remove fire hazards on their land.

However, it also advises that unauthorised removal of dead trees and vegetation on roadsides is forbidden. The conflict between the two would be laughable if it were not so serious. It is obvious that the roadsides are fire routes into the heart of our towns. Dead trees overhang the roads and if they fall, they would block the escape route for residents. Grass and fallen timber litter the roadsides. Certainly there is a need to provide a habitat for native wildlife and endangered plants but protection of residents must be the highest priority of any council.

Bill Wilson, Beechworth

The climate science is in

Kerry Stokes, we do not need to make "snap judgments" about responding to climate change (The Age, 14/11). The way forward has been well and truly documented for years - see all the reports by Ross Garnaut and others. But somehow the education system has failed the government and its members cannot read and understand those policy maps. Shame on them.

Peta Colebatch, Swan Reach

Our reckless disregard

Is anyone else interested in properly describing what confronts us? Not natural disasters and acts of Mother Nature. Rather unnatural disasters with Mother Nature on the run, as are the poor victims of our reckless disregard and failure to recognise and prioritise our health and the environment.

Pip Carew, South Melbourne

The crews in green

Several readers (Letters 12/11 and 13/11) have called for a paid, full-time fire fighting force to fight bushfires, reduce fuel loads and work with Aboriginal groups to learn traditional fire management. It is an excellent idea, that is why we already have it. Forest Fire Management, the crews in green overalls, do those things.

Peter Bear, Mitcham

Seeking rational thought

Barnaby Joyce and Craig Kelly's cringe-inducing comments about bushfires only reinforce the perennial call for aptitude testing for those seeking elected office. Our politicians must demonstrate a capacity for informed, rational thought. Unless hard evidence prevails over the current conservative cult of placing greater weight in "feelings" and "beliefs", subsequent discourse is only degraded. Our modern secular democracy deserves so much better.John Bond,

Croydon

Greens must accept blame

The Greens are correct that climate change makes bushfires more frequent and more intense. They know it now and they knew it in 2009 when they voted down the Rudd government's emissions trading scheme and joined with Tony Abbott's Liberals. The Greens should accept that they helped create the very situation no less than the political parties they deflect the blame to.

Phillip Edwards, Churchill

Dangerous daylight saving

Our Deputy Prime Minister is correct. It is only leftist greenies who bang on about climate change. And the situation would be much worse if Queensland had daylight saving. Imagine that extra hour of sun at the end of each day heating things up.Michael Brinkman,

Ventnor

Hope - just for a moment

For a moment my heart leapt as I read Jessica Irvine's article - "A speech we'd like to hear" Comment, 14/11). If only the Prime Minister could actually say and do what was in the piece, it could arrest and even turn around the serious continuing fall in trust in government that is undermining the whole country.

Marcus Wigan, Eaglemont

Vote 1 for Irvine

Jessica Irvine should write all of Scott Morrison's speeches. Better still, let's have her as prime minister.Cath Dyson, Mount Eliza

urn:contentItem:56BT-F6M1-F12F-F4FW-00000-00QUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE REMINDS RESIDENTS WITHIN IPSWICH AND SURROUNDING AREAS TO BE CAUTIOUS AND VIGILANT WITH EXPECTED HEIGHTENED FIRE DANGER RATING2012-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisQUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE REMINDS RESIDENTS WITHIN IPSWICH AND SURROUNDING AREAS TO BE CAUTIOUS AND VIGILANT WITH EXPECTED HEIGHTENED FIRE DANGER RATING

BRISBANE, Queensland, Aug. 14 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) is reminding residents within the Ipswich and surrounding areas to be cautious and vigilant with a heightened fire danger rating expected in the coming days.

QFRS South East Regional Manager Rural Operations Fergus Adrian said the very high to severe forest fire danger rating predicted for Thursday and Friday this week had been down-graded slightly to high to very high.

Measures are still being taken by firefighters to prepare for potential vegetation fires.

"We are expecting strong winds which will bring with them very dry conditions," he said.

"Residents in the Ipswich area, particularly around Amberley and surrounds should be vigilant."

Mr Adrian encouraged persons planning on conducting hazard reduction burns to re-evaluate their plans and consider delaying any such action.

"Anyone considering conducting hazard reduction burns should speak directly with their fire warden first," he said.

"Landowners who have conducted hazard reduction burns recently are strongly encouraged to take steps to ensure their fire has been properly extinguished or to make sure the residual fire is contained so that it will not escape with the forecast winds in the coming days."

Mr Adrian said firefighters were already starting to see fire activity around the region, which made it crucial for residents to make sure they were doing all they could to prepare their homes and properties.

"If they haven't done so already, I urge residents to finalise preparing their property and visit the Rural Fire Service website to download a bushfire survival plan so that no one is caught off guard," he said.

"We are also asking people to ensure they are not throwing cigarette butts out of car windows and to be careful when operating machinery in dry grassed areas."

More information about how to prepare for bushfire season can be found at www.ruralfire.qld.gov.au For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

BRISBANE, Queensland, Aug. 9 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) is reminding North Coast Region residents to be cautious and vigilant with a heightened fire danger rating expected in the coming days.

QFRS North Coast Regional Manager Rural Operations Peter Hollier said very high forest fire danger ratings were forecast for today and tomorrow and measures were being taken by firefighters to prepare for potential vegetation fires.

"We are expecting strong winds which will bring with them very dry conditions," he said.

"Residents in the western areas of the region, particularly around Monto, Gayndah and Kingaroy should be vigilant."

Mr Hollier encouraged persons planning on conducting hazard reduction burns to re-evaluate their plans and take extra precautions.

"Anyone considering conducting hazard reduction burns should speak directly with their fire warden first," he said.

"Landowners who have conducted hazard reduction burns recently are strongly encouraged to take steps to ensure their fire has been properly extinguished or to make sure the residual fire is contained so that it will not escape with the forecast winds in the coming days."

Mr Hollier said firefighters were already starting to see fire activity around the region, which made it crucial for residents to make sure they were doing all they could to prepare their homes and properties.

"If they haven't done so already, I urge residents to finalise preparing their property and visit the Rural Fire Service website to download a bushfire survival plan so that no one is caught off guard," he said.

"We are also asking people to ensure they are not throwing cigarette butts out of car windows and to be careful when operating machinery in dry grassed areas."

More information about how to prepare for bushfire season can be found at www.ruralfire.qld.gov.au For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:5H2T-1XM1-F0JP-W1PC-00000-00Springing into summer2015-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Springing into summerTIM WILLIAMS ROXANNE WILSON

AN EARLY burst of summer weather has boosted hopes of a surge in surf lifesaving membership, as figures reveal a dip in both nippers and adult patrollers last financial year.

Surf Life Saving SA is urging beachgoers enjoying the forecast 36C temperatures today - the third hottest October day in the past decade - to take extra care in the water because official patrols do not begin until Saturday.

The CFS issued fire bans for today for the Mount Lofty Ranges, Kangaroo Island and Lower South East districts, with the fire danger in the Adelaide Hills rated as "extreme".

Police last night urged the public to keep a lookout for firebugs after a deliberately lit forest fire at Mt Pleasant, while doctors raised concerns of severe sunburn.

Latest Surf Life Saving SA statistics show numbers of nippers, teenage cadets and adult life savers all fell about 5 per cent in 2014-15.

The number of youngsters in training was down from 3056 to 2889, active cadets (aged 15-18) from 821 to 777 and adult patrollers from 1952 to 1858, while total membership slipped 6 per cent from 9076 to 8534. CEO Clare Harris said there would be no problem staffing patrols this summer, though final registration figures were six weeks away.

"A lot of clubs have run registration days over the last couple of weeks but a lot of people leave it until the last minute," she said. "We want all our members to re-register and hopefully we get lots of new members." Despite the drop-off in 2014-15, long-term growth in the sport remains impressive, with a 90 per cent rise in nippers over the past decade.

SLSSA president John Baker said beachgoers coming "out of hibernation" should be extra vigilant around children and read signage carefully in the absence of patrols today, and realise they would be more prone to cramp if they had lost fitness over winter.

SA beaches can expect 9.2 million visitors over summer and 51 per cent of Adelaide residents will take at least one dip, Roy Morgan research shows.

The Australian Melanoma Research Foundation warned people risked being hospitalised with severe sunburn if they were "caught out" in the sudden burst of hot weather without adequate protection.

Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Vince Rowlands predicted a "warmer than average" lead-up to summer.

CFS crews battled a deliberately lit fire in a pine forest at Mt Pleasant that burned about a hectare of undergrowth. There were also grassfires at Brownlow, north east of the Barossa Valley, and Angaston.

"Arsonists sometimes practice with small fires, before lighting a devastating fire, so police encourage the public to report all suspicious fires, big or small, so they can be investigated," police said.

SLSSA emergency operations manager Andy Bedford put South Port nippers Tillie Zeitz, 9, and Axel Cunningham, 10, through their paces yesterday ahead of surf club open days this Saturday.

urn:contentItem:5PHG-D3P1-F0JP-W0S4-00000-00Life in the state's hot seat2017-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 28Life in the state's hot seatKATH SULLIVAN

It hasn't exactly been a baptism of fire for Victoria's new fire chief, writes KATH SULLIVAN STEPHANIE Rotarangi is responsible for more than eight million hectares of Victoria.

At least, as chief fire officer with the Victorian Department of Environment Land Water and Planning, she is responsible for managing fire on that land.

This week marks one year since her first day in the job in one of the world's most bushfire prone regions, one in which Dr Rotarangi (pictured) must manage the approval, planning and ignition of the state's planned burning schedule.

Describing DELWP's approach to planned burns as "a co-ordinated approach between technology and pragmatism" Dr Rotarangi says she has encountered no shortage of opinions on how the state can manage fire on its land.

"Planned burning is a conversation for all Victorians. How we live in this environment, how we mitigate the risk is a conversation I should expect," she says.

"Hectares are an arbitrary number, whereas what Victorians, I think, are really expecting of my teams and myself is to reduce the risk to their communities, so (a planned burn) 300ha around Lorne can have a much greater impact than 30,000ha in the back country." The first female and first Kiwi, to take up the role, Dr Rotarangi has more than 2500 staff working from 101 depots across the state in her charge.

Direct from New Zealand's Otago Rural Fire Authority, where she served as chief executive and principal rural fire officer - New Zealand's highest operational rank - Dr Rotarangi has more than 20 years' experience in forestry and fire management.

When it was announced in June last year that she would be crossing the ditch to join DELWP the Otago Daily Times suggested "like Phar Lap, Crowded House and pavlova, one of (its) best senior firefighters has been claimed by the Aussies".

In some ways Dr Rotarangi's first year as chief fire officer was made easier with a relatively quiet fire season - by March, Victoria had not experienced a bushfire that lasted more than several days.

"One of the benefits of a quieter fire season last year was my ability to get around and meet staff and meet other agency staff and meet community members," she says.

Admitting she had limited experience of Victoria before arriving here, Dr Rotarangi said she had "been on the road non-stop" since arriving.

"Is that enough? Definitively not, but there's only one way to approach it," she says.

The initiation was not without its challenges.

"There were a lot of emergencies across the state from floods - in my first week we were straight into floods - the spring was really quite volatile and incredibly wet.

"That ability to understand emergencies in terms of a number of hazards has been really good, working side-by-side with SES and Vic Police." In the course of her meeting with The Weekly Times, Dr Rotarangi singles out the ability of Victoria's emergency services to work together as "exceptional" on several occasions.

"It's the jewel in our crown," she says. "Gone are the days when any one agency can really meet all the needs of Victorian communities ... we all have our own statutory responsibilities, points of excellence really, but we work in a way that is collaborative â€¦ from the outside it might be hard to imagine how it is pieced together, but it provides a seamless service to the community." That includes working with the Country Fire Authority.

"I am really conscious of how lucky we are to work beside the CFA, particularly in planned burning, because the skills that they bring and the local knowledge they bring and dedication to the community is so commendable," Dr Rotarangi says.

It is likely DELWP's forest fire management crews will work closely with CFA on wildfire too, with an early start to the bushfire season forecast, particularly in the east of the state. "All the indicators at the moment are suggesting that much of Victoria will have an above average bush fire season," Dr Rotarangi says.

"So you might recall a pretty warm winter - it didn't feel like it, but it was quite a warm June and July - that causes a lot of growth to germinate.

"It is great for the farmers, but that means increased growth in the forests."Compounding concerns were a damp spring last year and a dry, warm autumn this year, which had created less than favourable planned burning conditions. DELWP last month announced it would bring planned burning forward as early as this month. Regardless, Dr Rotarangi says her crews are ready for the season.

urn:contentItem:5RCC-02T1-JD3N-50M4-00000-00PHEW, WHAT A SCORCHER2018-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4PHEW, WHAT A SCORCHERCHRIS HONNERY

QUEENSLANDERS sweltered through our hottest ever year in 2017, our warmest ever winter, and temperatures from Brisbane to Birdsville that scorched holes in the -record books.

Remarkably, the typical Queensland day peaked at 31.53C - the average daytime maximum temperature beating the previous record of 31.4C, set in 2013.

The state's average temperature of 24.63C for the year was the hottest since records began, beating the previous record of 24.48C in 2005.

Brisbane's warmest winter ever last year - an average of 23.51C from June to August - also added to the state's overall heat, which climatologists labelled an "interesting year".

The Bureau of Meteorology's Annual Climate Summary, released today, has highlighted the nation's extreme weather events in the past 12 months.

Brisbane had its equal-warmest year on record - tied with 2016 - with an average maximum temperature of 27.3C and an average minimum temperature of 17.1C.

Nationwide, the country sweated through its third-warmest year on record, with an average of 21.8C - 0.95C warmer than the long-term average.

The only significant cyclone to make landfall last year, Category 4 Cyclone Debbie, caused the strongest recorded wind gust in Queensland (263km/h at Hamilton Island) and the wettest day of the year (635mm at Mount Jukes).

However, rainfall was below average for central and western Queensland, with some areas near the Northern Territory border experiencing severe rainfall deficiencies.

BoM's head of climate monitoring Dr Karl Braganza said that several notable anomalies occurred in Queensland - including the equal-warmest year on record for the southeast.

"Queensland was one of the warmer parts of the country in 2017 and ... daytime maximum temperatures were very warm," he said.

"Over the winter period, daytime maximum temperatures reached record warmth across the southeast, southern interior and northwest Queensland and it was also extremely warm in February. Thargomindah reached a Queensland February record of 47.2C." Dr Braganza described Brisbane's weather in particular as "interesting" and "likely to be in the warmest five years on record for many maximum and mean overall temperatures".

"We saw the warmest January/ March on record and record warm days/ nights in September. It was also the wettest March on record for many locations across the Brisbane area," he said.

The climate report also highlighted prolonged warm ocean temperatures around the Great Barrier Reef, which caused unprecedented coral bleaching during March for the second consecutive year.

"(It's) the only incidence of back-to-back bleaching on record," Dr Braganza said.

It comes as authorities warn Queenslanders to be vigilant of the hot temperatures forecast across the state this week.

Queensland Ambulance Service clinical director Tony Hucker said that heat-related illness could become life-threatening.

"Heatstroke is the most serious heat-related illness that presents with symptoms similar to heat exhaustion, but which may also include an -extremely high body temperature; red, hot, dry skin, but possible some clamminess; a rapid pulse; headache and confusion," he said.

Acting Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Shannon Fentiman said that recent heatwave conditions in southern states provided a timely reminder for Queenslanders to stay safe in the heat.

"We want everyone to enjoy the summer holidays, so it's important everyone is aware of the risks associated with warm weather," Ms Fentiman said.

"The elderly, babies and young children, pregnant or breastfeeding women and those who suffer pre-existing medical conditions or take certain medications are most at-risk of heat-related illness.

"Physically active people, including those working outdoors and exposed to the -elements, should also be aware of the signs and symptoms of illness."
