urn:contentItem:457Y-MHF0-0197-53GT-00000-00<published>1997-10-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:44:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. S08</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IT'S ALL TRUE EVERY WORD</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PAT SHEIL</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WE HAVE all heard them. We've believed some of them, dismissed others and wondered quietly about the rest. They are urban myths, wild and crazy yarns dressed up as the gospel truth.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Internet is, if anything, not much more than an exponential explosion of this kind of stuff. So it's nice to know that there are people out there checking out the bona fides of some of these wacky anecdotes.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>The best urban myth site I've been able to find is the San Fernando Valley Folklore Society Urban Legends Reference Pages , established and maintained by Barbara and David Mikkelson. This site is so ridiculously comprehensive that one suspects that you are yet again being had a lend of. Nonetheless, the Mikkelsons are convincing, and their research seems to stand up.</p><p> They log in silly stories as they emerge and investigate their credentials, truth-wise. For those of us who have been worrying about the verisimilitude of the classic urban myths, they are here, too. Here is a sample from recent research questions that have emerged.</p><p> The seeing-eye dog who led four of his owners to their deaths.</p><p> True or false?</p><p> What was in the briefcase in the movie Pulp Fiction?</p><p> If Nigerian officials send a fax offering you a reward to help them get money into American banks, don't bother!</p><p>  (True!</p><p>I can vouch for this -and not just American banks, either.) The Mikkelsons specialise in certain areas, especially the Disney Corporation. I won't be buying into that one -Disney is reputed to have once sued a Miami kindergarten for unauthorised use of a Mickey Mouse image in a playground mural.</p><p> Here is a random selection from the Mikkelsons'</p><p>almost endless list of popular conundrums.</p><p>  JATO DEATH Claim: the remains of a smouldering JATO-assisted Chevrolet Impala were found embedded in the side of a cliff in the Arizona desert.</p><p> Status: false.</p><p> Of all the crazy faxlore stories, this has to be the one fellas love the most. There's something about cars and solid-fuel rocket engines that draws them to this tale.</p><p>Maybe it's the Wile  E  Coyote-ness of it all, the "so real you can almost touch it" mental image of a smouldering wreck sticking out of a cliff face.</p><p> It turns out that this story has been doing the rounds by e-mail and fax for two years or more. It has no basis in fact.</p><p> The Mikkelsons quote the International Herald Tribune, which tried to get to the bottom of the story in early 1996: "The story is not true, according to a spokesman for the Arizona Department of Public Safety, who should know.</p><p> " 'We get a call on that almost every 90 days,' said Dave Myers.</p><p> " 'It keeps us on the map.' "</p><p> You may have heard of this next one, too. I know I have. We ran a version of it in Picture magazine when I used to hunt these stories down for a living.</p><p> DEAD DRIVER IN A TREE Claim: in the aftermath of last year's forest fire in Malibu, the charred remains of a scuba diver were found in a tree.</p><p> Status: false.</p><p> Synopsis: fire authorities in California found a corpse in a burnt-out section of forest while assessing the damage done by a forest fire. The deceased male was dressed in a full wetsuit, complete with dive tank, flippers and face mask. A postmortem examination revealed that the person died not from burns but from massive internal injuries.</p><p>Investigators then set about determining how a fully clad diver ended up in the middle of a forest fire. It was revealed that on the day of the fire, the person went for a diving trip of the coast, some 20km away from the forest.</p><p> Here's the bit that makes this yarn so priceless: The fire-fighters, seeking to control the fire as quickly as possible, called in a fleet of helicopters with very large buckets. The buckets were dropped in to the ocean for rapid filling, then flown to the forest fire and emptied.</p><p>One minute our diver was in the Pacific, the next he was doing breaststroke in a fire bucket 300m in the air.</p><p>Apparently, he extinguished 1.78m of the fire.</p><p> Barbara Mikkelson theorises that this story is one of those hypothetical guessing-game scenarios, in this case, "How did this person die?" -a scenario that took on a life of its own. Sounds conceivable.</p><p> You will notice that all of these examples have been proved false, which is not always the case. This last story, which is true, comes with a note of warning. If you are eating breakfast, either stop reading or stop eating. The combination will not agree with you.</p><p> In fact, I advise you to not only avoid breakfast, but leave the kitchen altogether.</p><p>  SCROTUM SELF-REPAIR Claim: a machine-shop worker who made a regular practice of masturbating by holding his penis against the drive-belt of a piece of machinery, leant too close to the belt one day and caught his scrotum between the pulley wheel and the drive-belt.</p><p> The man suffered a torn scrotum and lost one of his testicles, but calmly stapled his scrotum back together and resumed work before visiting a doctor three days later.</p><p> Status : true.</p><p> Synopsis: this is an actual case that was reported in a letter submitted to the medical journal, Medical Aspects of Human Sexuality, in July 1991. We contacted the physician who penned the letter and obtained verification and further details about the unusual injury and its treatment.</p><p> The diligent Mikkelsons give us these "further details", chapter and verse, but I won't trouble you with them.</p><p> Crikey, I've already ruined my own breakfast!</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5MC8-1FF1-F031-X3NR-00000-00Remote area firefighters ready at a moment's notice to control bushfires before they spread2016-11-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisRemote area firefighters ready at a moment's notice to control bushfires before they spreadBill Brown

The dangerous bushfires you do not hear about are the ones extinguished by specialist firefighters in remote forests, before they can threaten lives and property.

Remote Area Firefighting Teams (RAFT) work in remote, rugged areas that cannot be accessed by firefighting tankers.

Lightning strikes are a common cause of bushfires in south-east New South Wales, one of the most forested areas of Australia with vast areas of remote mountainous terrain that is at risk of catastrophic bushfire every summer.

Aerial patrols together with a network of observation towers manned by the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) and the Forestry Corporation aim to locate fires as quickly as possible.

Teams of Rural Fire Service staff co-ordinate operations from fire control centres at Bega, Cooma and Moruya, supported by a network of volunteer brigades, including RAFT crews.

Four-person RAFT crews and a helicopter are always on stand-by to respond to the numerous fires caused by lightning each year.

Garry Cooper, RAFT co-ordinator at the RFS Control Centre at Bega, said the rapid response teams could be airborne within 15 to 20 minutes.

"They'll land if possible, or they'll hover the helicopter so the crews can get out. If not, they'll find a hole in the canopy of the trees and winch those four firefighters through the canopy to the fireground," he said.

The teams carry rake-hoes, axes and chainsaws.

"In most instances of a single lightning strike, it's definitely achievable to extinguish with a crew of four," Mr Cooper said.

Team members need wide range of skills

The team's task is primarily to contain the fire by clearing a perimeter around it, cutting down any burning trees, and calling in a water-bombing helicopter.

"If they haven't got water-bombing support, all they can use is chainsaws, axes, and more or less use their feet and their hands to do the work," Mr Cooper said.

The crews need to pass a rigorous medical and fitness test and are highly trained in firefighting techniques.

They must have good bush skills in navigation, and the ability to work in dangerous environments well away from vehicle support.

The RFS and NPWS have RAFT teams, and sometimes they call on teams from ACT Parks as well.

"It's a dangerous line of work," said Brian Levine, a RAFT co-ordinator with ACT Parks.

"It's steep, hazardous terrain, so footing is crucial. Each step needs to be with purpose. And then, of course, fire-weakened trees are hazardous trees."

Mr Cooper said it was not an option to just a leave a remote fire to burn.

"That small fire will continue to grow if nothing is done. And if it gets hit with very hot days and strong north-westerly winds, then it can grow and move hundreds of kilometres in a couple of days," he said.

"We've got a lot of villages that would be exposed. A fire coming out of that country is going to impact on a lot of people."

Sometimes the conditions worsen and the rapid response crew cannot contain the fire.

Before being dropped in they will have planned an escape route, and the helicopter is ready to get them out.

Big forest fire requires a huge operation

"If it's too big, then the control centre will ramp up the operation with additional aircraft and additional crews," Mr Cooper said.

"The basis of firefighting is good planning and good management."

Staging posts are then established as close to the fireground as possible, providing helicopter landing sites to transport crews, while trucks shuttle in fuel for the helicopters.

An incident management team working from the fire control centre will be assigned to the fire, including operational, planning, and mapping staff.

"The largest fires require a lot of people," Mr Cooper said.

"All agencies will be involved, including police, ambulance, SES, volunteer rescue, Salvation Army, Red Cross.

"All those people come together to form one big cell - to keep the firefighters hydrated and fed, to keep the operation running.

"We've got day shifts and nights shifts of firefighting crews on the ground, supported by operations teams day and night."

urn:contentItem:4T73-3760-TX4S-M1KK-00000-00Spirit of Beijing descends on Aranda2008-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisAPg. 14Spirit of Beijing descends on ArandaThe Canberra Times

THERE were cheers and squeals at Aranda Primary School yesterday as students had a surprise visit from five oversized friends.

Fuwa the Beijing Olympic Mascot gang stopped in to say "Ni Hao" to the school and to spread a little Olympic goodwill. And after the week the International Olympic Committee has had, these big-blowup guys seem to have their work cut out for them.

But yesterday, happily, it was all innocence and smiles at the primary school, the students adding to the Oriental atmosphere in a sea of red uniforms.

Designed to express the playful qualities of five children who form an intimate circle of friends, Fuwa also represent four of China's most popular animals the fish, the panda, the Tibetan antelope, the swallow with the quintet rounded out by the cartoonish Olympic flame.

Each of Fuwa has a rhyming two-syllable name, a traditional way of expressing affection for children in China. Beibei, the fish, Jingjing, the panda, Huanhuan, the Olympic flame, Yingying, the Tibetan antelope and Nini, the swallow.

When their names together are put together in this order Bei Jing Huan Ying Ni they say "Welcome to Beijing," in Mandarin.

The five elements of nature the sea, forest, fire, earth and sky are stylistically rendered in the mascot's ways to represent influences of Chinese folk art and ornamentation.

urn:contentItem:582Y-ND91-F031-X1HJ-00000-00Questions raised over fatal Thai refugee camp fire2013-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisQuestions raised over fatal Thai refugee camp fireBy South East Asia correspondent Zoe Daniel

There are claims a fire that ravaged a refugee camp in northern Thailand, killing 37 people and injuring 100, might not have been an accident.

The fire broke out at the Mae Surin camp in a remote region of north-west Thailand just over a week ago.

The camp is home to refugees from Myanmar, and around 2,300 are now homeless.

Now there are allegations that the devastating fire was intentional.

Some eyewitnesses claim they saw burning objects falling from a helicopter.

Thai media have reported that traces of the chemical phosphorous were found in the house where the fire was thought to have started.

Sally Thompson, the executive director of The Border Consortium, which works with refugees, says there are three different stories.

"One is that it started accidentally through a spark from a cooking pot in the camp," she told Saturday AM.

"Another is that it was from a spark from a forest fire in the surrounding area that has come into the camp.

"And then more recently some people have also said that they had seen a helicopter and a burning object coming from the sky."

District police chief Colonel Nitinart Wittayawuthikul says witnesses have also told him conflicting stories about what happened.

"I got the answer from witnesses that it came from a fireball that flew from the sky. They saw a helicopter, a white one, they said," he said.

"This is what the local witnesses said, about 10 to 20 of them.

"At the same time, many of them said that it was caused by a cooking fire."

The police chief has since been transferred from his post.

It is alleged that he was negligent and failed to respond properly to the fire.

He says he has been moved because he will not declare the fire an accident.

"It was three o'clock - who would be doing cooking?"

"My answer is that it wouldn't be from a cooking fire accident."

The secretary general of Thailand's National Security Council has dismissed the allegation, saying the fire was probably accidental because there is no motive for arson.

Thai police are currently investigating the camp fire, and say they hope to find the exact cause of the blaze.

The camp will now apparently be rebuilt.

urn:contentItem:5XD6-XHY1-JD3N-51TC-00000-00Those dystopian days2019-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 23Those dystopian daysGRAEME BLUNDELL, FIRST WATCH

Years and Years, the series that charts the rise of a populist dictator, is a story for our times

Years and Years is from Russell T. Davies, the Queer as Folk creator and the producer who reimagined Doctor Who so successfully, and it's fast becoming the most talked about show of the year, along with the second season of Succession. And, inspired by both the election of Donald Trump and the Brexit vote, there's a neat conceit at its centre.

It tells the story of the rise of a populist dictator, Viv Rook, played by Emma Thompson, but does it not by concentrating events on her terrifying rise to power - the political mechanics of her ascension - but rather on the ordinary people affected. And through their interactions slowly it reveals a measured, plausible, almost unremarkable transition to tyranny.

"It's been boiling away in my mind for a long time, but over the past few years the world itself seems to have been boiling faster and hotter and wilder than ever," Davies says on the BBC's media site. "I mean, the age, today, just seems fevered - we're either more political, or more scornful of politics, than ever. And I think, in the past, politics meant the economy to most people, but now we're seeing that it's our identity at stake." Beginning in 2019, with Trump still building his walls and British parliament not having worked out the troublesome Irish backstop, we encounter the extended Lyons family in Manchester one night, a diverse lot in race, sexual preference, gender identity and physical disability, presided over by Gran, played with sardonic edge by Anne Reid. Her grandchildren are Stephen, Daniel and Rosie (Rory Kinnear, Russell Tovey and Ruth Madeley). And then there's Jessica Hynes's Edith, an activist somewhere overseas again saving the planet. There's also a host of husbands, wives, sisters, sons and daughters, and Rosie's half-Chinese baby, Lincoln.

They're worried about the world they live in - the banks, politics, corporations and America with its fake news and false facts.

Tovey's Daniel sums it up early on, young Lincoln in his arms. "Don't know if I could, have a kid in a world like this," he says. "If it's this bad now, what's it going to be like for you in 30, 10, five years?" Then, beautifully on cue, Davies always a whiz with timing, the family drama is propelled forward in time, year by year, in a series of surprising and witty montages. Trump is re-elected, Angela Merkel dies ("Good riddance," remarks the omnipresent Rook, hardly off the TV as the years roll on so rapidly. "The world just got a whole lot prettier.") And by 2024 life has become more unbearable. London is overrun by refugees from the Ukraine, some areas requiring means-testing for entry, the border deal with Ireland has still not been settled and unrest is everywhere.

All this happens around the tight-knit Lyons family, an extended bunch who somehow manage to talk with each other constantly, always in and out of each other's lives, as they navigate extremist politics, climate change and even more technological encroachments on life. Stephen and wife Celeste have a major problem with daughter Bethany, who is in "transition": she wants to be transhuman or fully digital, her brain downloaded into the cloud so she can live forever as data.

And Viv Rook's populism is on the rise as she forms her own political movement to represent the people abandoned by the big, old parties. She calls it The Four Star Party, after the **** used by newspapers to convey the f-word she utters on TV the first time we see her. (Asked a question about Israel and Palestine on some talk show, she says, "I don't give a f..k, all I want is for my bins to be collected every week".) Davies cleverly positions Rook's development so that while central to the story she remains peripheral to the action, her face and voice constantly coming at us from ubiquitous TV screens.

Yes, this is bleak drama, so cleverly juxtaposing social realism, a kind of sci-fi dystopianism and a caustically satirical look at populist politics but it's surprisingly funny in places, with Davies admitting he can't write more than six lines without putting in a gag, witty and clever. And there's a romance, too, between Daniel, who's discovered his recent marriage to his boyfriend is all he wished for, and asylum-seeker Victor, a young Ukrainian who fled Kiev after being tortured by the Russian-allied authorities for being gay. But it's the life force of this wonderfully close family that sticks in the mind after you watch and the way that through them we gain such insights into politics and society.

Be prepared - Davies, always the magician, pulls a ferocious surprise out of his writer's hat just before the first episode ends, horrifically changing the nature of reality for the Lyons family just as they enjoy the annual outdoor birthday bash for grandmother Muriel.

The new TV version of the classic HG Wells story, The War of the Worlds, first published in serial format in Pearson's Magazine in 1897, is certainly different to anything we've seen before. Wells's story is a template for many such alien invasion stories to come. This time it's adapted by Peter Harness, best known for his writing on Doctor Who and directed by the experienced British director Craig Viveiros, who gave us the BBC's classy 2015 adaptation of Agatha Christie's And Then There Were None, and serial-killer drama Rillington Place.

At a time when the British exported war to distant shores in all their pompous greatness, Wells launched his alien forces into the cosy surroundings of southern England itself, infuriated by the wanton extermination of indigenous races in imperial wars.

"We must remember what ruthless and utter destruction our own species has wrought, not only upon animals, such as vanished bison and the dodo, but upon its own inferior races," his narrator says in the novel, citing the way "the Tasmanians were entirely swept out of existence in a war of extermination waged by European immigrants, in the space of 50 years".

And through many relocations and successive reworkings, including not only the famous realistic radio adaptation of Orson Welles that caused a nationwide panic in the US, but films, TV series and even popular music albums, Wells's work has encapsulated the paranoia of successive ages. Whether the fear of the Nazis in the late 1930s, the Cold War in the 1950s or Steven Spielberg's hardly subtle paralleling of the 9/11 terrorist attack.

And this new version seems to stem from the Brexiteers' dystopian fantasy of domination from the continent - almost as if defeated in a war - that has become indistinguishable from reality, haunting the imagination of British conservatism; unfortunately, it's hard to know from the first episode, a rather infuriating and -meandering affair.

Almost all adaptations of Wells's story, including the Spielberg movie, have been set in the modern time in which the project was produced. But Harkness sets his reimagining in the Victorian setting of the source material, re-creating the original in a way that has not often been seen.

The minister in London, who is filling in for the absent Prime Minister, on being informed that a strange object has landed from above, insists there's nothing to be worried about. That is after he's assured it couldn't possibly be the Russians who are currently causing a fuss attacking British ships up in the North Sea.

After all, it might just be a shooting star that extinguished itself near the sleepy town of Woking in Surrey, or a small meteorite that has caused a local forest fire. Or just an act of God that has caused some rock to drop from the -heavens.

But George and Amy, the two protagonists in Harkness's version, know better. They are young lovers ostracised from formal society trying to establish a new life for themselves after George, a London journalist, has left his embittered wife and a miserable marriage largely engineered by his well-to-do family, his brother a big wig at the Admiralty. Their friend Ogilvy, an astronomer and scientist who is the first to see some explosive plumes that he telescopically spots on the surface of Mars, also is making a new life. Soon they witness the landing of a giant meteorite containing a cylinder that lands in the rural countryside of Woking, Surrey, where George and Amy have settled.

Before long, heat rays emanate from the cylinder, devastating the crowds that gather, and George and Amy are on the run from a group of massive newly assembled tripodal war machines, looming mechanisms designed to exterminate human beings with remorseless rapidity and -efficiency.

Unlike the machines, the series is a creaky, rather wobbly piece of work, the chronology alone a cause for the shaking of heads. Thankfully, though, a cast that includes Eleanor Tomlinson as Amy, Rafe Spall as George, Robert Carlyle as Ogilvie and Rupert Graves as George's brother, Freddie, battles as courageously as the characters as they attempt to survive the invasion with some credibility intact.

Years and Years, Wednesday, SBS, 8.30pm.War of the Worlds, Thursday, Fox One, 7.30pm.

urn:contentItem:53G0-MSD1-F0JP-W55N-00000-00Crews battle blazes as fire season starts early2011-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Crews battle blazes as fire season starts earlyKate Higgins

EMERGENCY crews yesterday battled three major blazes around the state as firefighters warned of an early start to the fire season.

At O'Connell, south of Gladstone, residents were warned to enact their bushfire plans and evacuate if necessary after a fire was reported at 9.53am.

The warnings were withdrawn at 1.15pm when the fire was contained. Crews were last night monitoring and patrolling the site.

Further southwest at Calliope, two cars and a shed were damaged in a 100ha grass fire.

At Sandy Ridges, 22km east of Kingaroy, 14 urban and rural fire crews were called in to control another 100ha blaze. Both fires were contained by 4.30pm.

Queensland Fire and Rescue Service regional manager for rural operations John Fisher said the fire season, which usually began in early September, appeared to have started about four weeks early.

He said a combination of three good grass-growing seasons and strong winter winds were to blame.

``There's grass and fire fuels anywhere you go, so any sort of spark that escapes is going to be able to grow to any size it wants,'' Mr Fisher said. ``Because (grass fuels) are so continuous across the landscape, any small fire we get, unless we get on to it very quickly, will grow very quickly into a very big fire. If you get the wind behind it, it will move very fast.''

But he said bushfires would not necessarily pose as great a risk.

``There are two forms of fire, you can have a grass fire or you can have a forest fire,'' he said.

``The forest community we've got here doesn't have as much understory in it. It takes longer for it to grow back after drought.

``There's a lot more grass out there than there is forest.''

urn:contentItem:802B-STC0-Y9Y8-N0RV-00000-00Black Saturday report ready for release2010-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisLateline11:34 PM AESTABCJane CowanBlack Saturday report ready for release

LEIGH SALES, PRESENTER: The Royal Commission into the Black Saturday bushfires was set up to investigate Australia's worst bushfire disaster, which claimed 173 lives in February last year.

Tomorrow it'll hand down its much-anticipated report and the commissioners are likely to recommend a substantial overhaul of bushfire policy.

Jane Cowan reports.

JANE COWAN, REPORTER: Call it a firestorm or a mega fire, for those swept up in Black Saturday it sometimes felt like a black hole.

DAVID MCGAHY, FIRE CAPTAIN: I've got people up there that are dead and dying literally on the side of the road! I said, "I can't ..." - it's a horrendous scene. I said, "Will you come and help me?" And the chap on the - the officer on the roadblock said to me, "I can't do it; I'm under orders."

JANE COWAN: Applying the forensic to the impossibly emotional, the Royal Commission unearthed a shocking array of failures, the worst among them the failure to properly warn communities as fire bore down.

SHARON MCCULLOCH, SURVIVOR (9 June, 2009): I heard the beep, beep, beep of the 10 o'clock news and the message was something that Kinglake's under ember or under fire attack and I just remember thinking, "Well, that's a little bit too late."

JANE COWAN: At the highest levels of emergency management, the Commission's lawyers have said leadership was missing in the hour of crisis.

JACK RUSH, COUNSEL ASSISTING THE COMMISSION: It's, as we say, as if the senior fire personnel were powerless behind the glass, unable or unwilling to influence or attempt to influence the tragedy that was unfolding.

JANE COWAN: Whole towns were wiped out and whole families.

PAULINE ZEALLEY, SURVIVOR (17 Nov., 2009): We thought that maybe the kids were in the car and not with their mummy and daddy and we couldn't live with that.

JANE COWAN: Those at the helm struggled to explain it.

EWAN WALLER, FOREST FIRE CHIEF (26 June, 2009): Um, I'm ... (gesturing as if lost for words).

JANE COWAN: At the heart of the Commission's investigations has been the "stay or go" policy which has formed the bedrock of advice to bushfire-prone communities across Australia.

KRISTINE HANSCOMBE, COUNSEL FOR FIREFIGHTERS UNION: 173 people are dead who presumably intended to look after themselves. This policy has plainly failed.

COMMISSION QUESTIONER: The policy tells you not to use the road; this gives you advice what to do if you are on the road. How is someone s'posed to understand this?

BRUCE ESPLIN, EMERGENCY SERVICES COMMISSIONER (8 May, 2009): My understanding is that the CFA and the DSE have already started a process of reviewing the language in those messages.

JANE COWAN: The Commission's lawyers want the policy scrapped and replaced with a combination of voluntary evacuations and refuges.

Whatever the commissioners recommend though, the Victorian Premier John Brumby has announced a plan to consult the community before committing to anything, a move that's provoked dismay and suspicion.

KEVIN TOLHURST, FIRE SCIENTIST: To say that it needs more public consultation I think is just really a ploy to say, "Well, we made this decision because the community said so." Now I think that's a hiding behind the community screen, I think.

ATHOL HODGSON, FORMER FOREST FIRE CHIEF: The Premier's off on a sham consultation process. ... The mood's turned angry, very, very angry.

BOB CAMERON, EMERGENCY SERVICES MINISTER: You take for example the volunteers of the CFA. You know, we have an arrangement with the volunteers of the CFA that we consult with them about decisions which affect them. Now, that necessarily means that we have to consult.

JOAN DAVEY, SURVIVOR: I think 18 months of evidence and - we've had the debate, John; let's do some action. Let's make some decisions, please.

LOU SIGMUND, VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTER: We need radical change but I doubt anybody has got the testicles to do that.

JANE COWAN: Two of those at the helm on Black Saturday, the then police and fire chiefs, are already out of the picture, each having quit.

The Brumby Government can't be blamed for the firestorm or for policies established before its time, but with a state election in November it can be judged on what's done now to prevent another black day.

Jane Cowan, Lateline.

urn:contentItem:5V8D-JV31-JD34-V4G6-00000-00Dire fire conditions ahead; firefighters plead for safe conduct2019-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisDire fire conditions ahead; firefighters plead for safe conductEmma D'Agostino

SENIOR firefighters have urged people to reconsider activities that might heighten the risk of heat-related emergencies, amid concern about fire conditions.

Friday is a day of statewide Total Fire Ban.

Extreme heat and blustery conditions have been forecast for much of the state, and leading firefighters at both state and local levels have warned of the associated dangers.

CFA Chief Officer Steve Warrington said the next four, six and up to eight weeks were paramount for bushfires in Victoria.

"If you look at our history here in Victoria, most of the bad days have been one-day events where there has been significant life lost and property loss, and that's on the back of an extended period of drought for a number of years, and weeks of heatwave," he said.

He said recent conditions reflected some of the terrible times in the state's past.

"Let's learn from it, let's work together, let's make sure all Victorians are safe," Mr Warrington said.

He said the state's firefighters were skilled and rehearsed at what they needed to do.

"The message is, what do the community do?" Mr Warrington said.

"Make sure you're well and truly aware of your environment and have a plan of what you're actually going to do, should a fire occur."

He urged people to download the VicEmergency app, check fire danger ratings and be aware of emergency broadcasters, both at home and in any area they might be visiting during the Australia Day long weekend.

RELATED: Epsom, White Hills among first Bendigo hotspots to emerge from new tracker

CFA District 2 rostered duty officer Chris Jacobsen said firefighters had been preparing and planning for the local conditions.

He urged people to put off any activity that would usually see them out in the bush or in dry grass until conditions changed, and to consider the impact their actions could have on others - including firefighters.

"It's just bloody selfish if people are doing things likely to cause a fire when they shouldn't be," Mr Jacobsen said.

He said people ought to ensure they were complying with restrictions applicable during the Fire Danger Period and Total Fire Ban days.

"We're hoping all our volunteers and staff can enjoy their Australia Day," Mr Jacobsen said.

Heat health alerts have been issued in relation to Friday's weather.

The Eaglehawk Landfill will be closed for the day to limit windblown litter and dust.

Thursday's heat will carry into the evening and intensify on Friday, the Bureau of Meteorology has predicted.

BOM senior forecaster Richard Carlyon said temperatures would move into the 40s fairly early on Friday, peaking at 46 degrees in the state's north west.

Bendigo is forecast to reach a top of 45 degrees, with a late cool change.

While parts of Victoria might experience a sharp drop in temperature once the change sweeps through, Mr Carlyon said the effect would be less pronounced in the state's north.

"They'll probably notice a six - eight degree drop as that front moves through, but still quite warm conditions when you think about the temperature dropping from the mid-40s to the high 30s," he said.

BOM predicts Friday's weather will generally be humid, but the fire danger in most parts of the state will still be severe. Conditions in the Mallee and North Central districts will be extreme, and conditions in the North East and East Gippsland will be very high.

"It [the humidity] does make it more uncomfortable and it does add to heat stress," Mr Carlyon said.

RELATED: Blackouts not likely as power supply remains secure according to AEMO

A state controller for heat has been appointed, effective until Saturday.

Justin Dunlop said it was important people take steps to keep cool.

"Plan your days so you're not exercising in extreme heat, you're not travelling in the extreme heat, and you're carrying water with you if you're travelling, particularly if you're travelling into the country to enjoy the long weekend," he said.

He said people should keep well hydrated and look out for one another.

Mr Dunlop recommended people touch base with vulnerable community members.

Pleas not to leave children, pets or loved ones in cars were reiterated, as more than 300 incidents had been recorded since December 1.

"Look before you leave your car - make sure you don't leave anyone behind accidentally," Mr Dunlop said.

Environment Protection Authority Victoria has also warned of the potential for increased dust levels, ozone or smoke from bushfires.

"Smoky and dusty conditions are particularly hazardous to people with asthma and other lung conditions, those with heart conditions, young children, seniors and pregnant women," Dr Andrea Hinwood, the EPA's chief environmental scientist, said.

"We're asking people take it slow and limit prolonged or heavy outdoor physical activity. And if you're struggling, your furry friends could be too so keep them indoors with you, if possible."

Live air quality results are available on AirWatch.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp is expecting people will be out and about during the Australia Day long weekend.

He expected the heat would make the state's coastal areas and waterways all the more attractive.

"And that's natural... and we want people to enjoy themselves and cool down in the water," Mr Crisp said.

"However, when you're doing that, if you're at the beaches swim at a patrolled beach... swim between the flags.

"If you're at inland waterways, go to where the locals are swimming. If you don't know the area, ask a local. Know the conditions in which you're swimming."

Mr Crisp said there had been 20 drowning deaths since December 1.

"We don't want to see another one this weekend. Please, let's take something from these drowning deaths that have occurred."

Forest Fire Management Victoria has also advised people considering camping in the Loddon Mallee region to play it safe and do the right thing, especially when it comes to fire restrictions.

FFMVic's Jeff Wilkie said it was everyone's responsibility to ensure they know if a Total Fire Ban had been declared and what they could or could not do on such days.

Camp fires are banned on a day of Total Fire Ban, such as Friday.

Restrictions apply on any day during the Fire Danger Period.

About 10 per cent of Victoria's fires are caused by campfires.

Mr Wilkie said on-the-spot fines of up to $476 applied for people who did not comply with campfire regulations, and people could face a maximum penalty of up to $15,872 if the matter was prosecuted in court.

He said authorised officers would be out patrolling from Gunbower Island out to Echuca during the long weekend.

RELATED: CFA declare total fire ban for Victoria on Friday

FFMVic Loddon Mallee assistant chief fire officer Scott Falconer said illegal campfires, dumping rubbish, damaging forest roads and vandalism were unacceptable.

"We encourage everyone to respect the bush and use bins provided or take their rubbish home with them," he said.

People keen to explore the outdoors at the long weekend should also drink plenty of water and look after others.

"Animals can also be affected by hot weather," Mr Falconer said.

"If you come across wildlife that appear lethargic, non-responsive or sick, contact a wildlife rehabilitation organisation, vet or Wildlife Shelter or Foster Carer for further assistance."

urn:contentItem:4SJG-33G0-TX5N-00HJ-00000-00Javier swaps Spain for bushfires of WA2008-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisPg. 16Javier swaps Spain for bushfires of WA

Inset: DEC staff Owen Donovan, Javier Martin Morena Meijias and Rick Sneeuwjagt. And above, Javier gets to work in a DEC bulldozer.

YOUNG Spanish forester Javier Martin Morena Meijias came to WA a year ago fired up to improve his English and enjoy the good weather- and he has ended up fighting fires as well.

He trained as a forest engineer in Spain and joined the Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) to learn more about forest and wildfire control.

His experience has turned out to be very hands-on, fighting as a seasonal firefighter with DECs Wanneroo office, taking part in fire training courses and attending some of the biggest fires of the season.

He has also assisted with experimental burns with the DEC Science Divisions fire research team and has helped compile maps in preparation for the fire season ahead.

I wanted to learn English and Australians were the friendliest English-speaking people I met in Europe. Plus Australia has the best weather and most different landscapes to Spain, Mr Morena said.

He has also been able to teach DEC staff about forest fire management in Spain, based on his experience with the Spanish National Research Institute of Agriculture and Forestry.

DEC Fire Management Services branch manager Rick Sneeuwjagt said WA and Spain had much in common with respect to the Mediterranean fire climate and vegetation fuels.

urn:contentItem:4P2C-STH0-TX53-732M-00000-00200 homes go in fierce fires2007-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 14

wire

200 homes go in fierce fires

SAN FRANCISCO: Firefighters tackled a ferocious forest fire near California's Lake Tahoe yesterday that destroyed up to 220 homes and forced the evacuation of 1000 people.

The blaze, which officials said was deliberately lit, erupted on Sunday on dry forest land near the southern tip of Lake Tahoe, a popular tourist spot 300km northeast of San Francisco.

By Monday evening, the flames had scorched around 1011 hectares and 750 firefighters were attempting to halt their advance, officials said.

A US Forest Service spokesman said favourable weather conditions had enabled teams of firefighters backed by water-dropping aircraft to make significant progress, with the fire now 40 per cent contained.

''Evidently it has been a very good day,'' said forest service information officer Todd Chaponot. ''The weather helped a lot. The wind dropped off and the humidity increased.''

He said officials had set a containment date of July 1.

Thick smoke across the affected area gradually cleared yesterday, allowing previously grounded firefighting aircraft to take to the skies.

''Initially the visibility was so bad they couldn't fly,'' Mr Chaponot said.

Earlier, California officials declared a state of emergency in the area affected by the fire, which local officials described as the worst in memory.

Homes destroyed in the blaze were mostly in residential areas, they said.

urn:contentItem:7TYJ-NFW0-Y9Y8-S10G-00000-00Adelaide fire threat recedes2009-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisAdelaide fire threat recedes

The South Australian Country Fire Service (CFS) says the threat to public safety posed by a fire at Gawler River, in Adelaide's north, has reduced.

The fire started near Wilkinson Road and Gawler River Road and travelled in a south-easterly direction towards Munno Para, Kudla, Hillier and Angle Vale.

The CFS says residents can now return to the area, but smoke remains in the region and visibility may be reduced.

Residents are advised to check their properties for embers in roof spaces and gutters.

Wind gusts of up to 90kph had been predicted, along with temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius.

It was 37C in Adelaide at 9:00am ACDT but the temperature has since fallen to 34C.

More than 10,000 firefighters and 11 water bombers are on stand-by in strategic positions around the state.

One water bomber has already been sent to help contain a forest fire at Nangwarry near Mount Gambier.

National parks at Mount Lofty and on the Fleurieu Peninsula are closed because of the bushfire threat, and Monarto Zoo is also closed.

The SES emergency number is 132 500 and the South Australian Country Fire Service information hotline is 1300 362 361.

Black-outs

More than 8,000 homes are without power in the northern suburbs of Adelaide.

An ETSA spokesman says the black-outs are most likely due to tree limbs that have fallen on powerlines.

He says power should be restored within a few hours.

Suburbs affected include Gawler, Parafield Gardens and Ingle Farm.

Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
   SUVA, March 15 AFP - Vanuatu's president has made an emotional appeal for international help after his island nation was hit by a category five cyclone, wreaking devastation in what is feared to be one of the region's worst weather disasters. (PAM Update)


  
   KOLKATA, March 14 AFP - Police in eastern India say they are investigating the gang-rape of a 75-year-old nun by burglars who broke into the convent school where she lived. (INDIA RAPE)
   ATHENS, March 14 AFP - Greece's combative finance minister has indicated that Athens' new radical left government is prepared to put some of its campaign promises on hold while it seeks to build confidence among its creditors. (CRISIS GREECE)
   YANGON, March 14 AFP - Rescuers have been frantically searching for survivors after an overloaded ferry sank in rough waters off the coast of western Myanmar killing more than 30 people and leaving at least a dozen more missing. (MYANMAR FERRY Update)
   BRUSSELS, March 14 AFP - EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini is due to visit Cuba later this month in a bid to advance nearly year-long talks with the Communist island state, the first such trip by a top EU diplomat. (CUBA EU Update)
   FREETOWN, March 14 AFP - Sierre Leone's Vice President Sam Sumana has applied for asylum at the US embassy in Freetown and is in hiding while his request is considered, a source close to him says. (SIERRA SUMANA)
   SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt, March 14 AFP - Egypt has secured billions of dollars in investment deals and aid pledges at a conference hailed as a show of support for President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and his fight against jihadists. (EGYPT ECONOMY)
   COPENHAGEN, March 14 AP - Swedish artist Lars Vilks, the main speaker at a seminar in Copenhagen targeted by a gunman a month ago, has received a freedom of speech prize. (DENMARK VILKS)
   BAGHDAD, March 14 AP - The Kurdish government in Iraq says it has evidence examined by an independent laboratory confirming that the Islamic State group used chlorine gas as a chemical weapon against peshmerga fighters. (IRAQ GAS)
   VALPARASO, Chile, March 14 AFP - Thousands of residents of Valparaiso have begun returning to their homes, hours after fleeing a still-smouldering forest fire that threatened the treasured Chilean seaport city, a UNESCO World Heritage site. (CHILE FIRE)
   SANAA, March 14 AFP - Yemeni political forces who oppose the Shi'ite militia that has seized control of Sanaa have formed an alliance against it, saying they want to restore state authority and rebuild weakened security forces. (YEMEN)
   YAOUNDE, March 14 AP - Cameroonian authorities say 25 Boko Haram suspects died in custody late last year but deny the country's army carried out regular human rights abuses against the extremist group. (CAMERON BOKO)
   BELGRADE, March 14 AP - Officials say a Serbian military helicopter has crashed near Belgrade while evacuating a sick baby from the south of the country, killing all seven people on board. (SERBIA HELICOPTER)

urn:contentItem:57FX-5BF1-DYG0-93DT-00000-00FED:Bushfire situation around Australia2013-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:Bushfire situation around Australia

  BUSHFIRES AUST SNAPSHOT
   BUSHFIRE SITUATION AROUND AUSTRALIA
  
   NSW
   Dozens of homes under threat as NSW firefighters battle 135 blazes in 40-plus temperatures and "catastrophic" conditions.


   The worst fires were in the south, near Cooma, Nowra, Bega and Wagga.
   Although 40 fires remained uncontained, by mid-afternoon there had been no reports of loss of life or homes.
   Other "emergency" alerts were at Oura, Mates Gully and Munyabla, near Wagga, and Narrandera, southwest of Wagga.
   Up to 90 per cent of NSW was in severe danger, with conditions officially described as catastrophic in the Illawarra, Shoalhaven and Southern Ranges.
   A total fire ban is in place across NSW.
  
   TAS
   A bushfire emergency warning has been issued for Kellevie and Bream Creek in the southeast and Mathinna in the northeast.
   The Tasman Peninsula blaze is threatening the small bayside towns of Eaglehawk Neck, Pirates Bay and Doo Town.
   Around 40 bushfires continue to burn across the state, with uncontrolled blazes at Montumana in the northwest and Lake Repulse in the Derwent Valley also causing concern.
   More than 550 houses have been searched and no bodies found, although about 100 people are still unaccounted for.
  
   VIC
   An eight hectare grassfire has burnt the fences of several Sunbury homes in Melbourne's northwest.
   The Kentbruck fire in Victoria's southwest continues to burn, threatening the commnuity of Drik Drik, while authorities are on alert for severe fire conditions in the state's north
  
   SA
   A string of bushfires continue to burn across northern South Australia but are not causing concern.
   The fires, including some which have been burning since Christmas, are in remote areas and are just being left to burn.
  
   QLD
   Eight bushfires are burning across Queensland but none are posing a threat to property.
   However, fire authorities are on high alert with a week of extremely hot weather about to hit the state.
  
   NT
   A bushfire in central Australia forced guests at the Kings Canyon Resort, about 300km southwest of Alice Springs, to evacuate for several hours.
  
   ACT
   A forest fire is burning in the ACT's south, close to Mount Ginini in the western region of Namadgi National Park but is under control.
   A total fire ban has been declared for Tuesday in the ACT, with fire danger rated at extreme due to forecast very hot and windy weather.
  
   WA
   WA has so far avoided bushfires.

urn:contentItem:55B9-4X01-F0J6-J533-00000-00Danger period ends2012-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Danger period ends

OFFICIAL fire danger restrictions across south-west Victoria will be lifted earlier than anticipated as the region heads towards weekend Easter rain and the winter months.

Compared with heightened caution at the start of summer, fire authorities are now confident the main bushfire risk has passed.

Restrictions for Country Fire Authority district five covering City of Warrnambool and shires of Moyne and Southern Grampians will be lifted on Monday, district six which covers Corangamite and Colac Otway is likely to be lifted in a fortnight while district four which covers Glenelg Shire will be evaluated after Easter.

All CFA district leaders told The Standard yesterday milder weather conditions had reduced the likelihood of further major fires.

They said the region had escaped the summer remarkably well apart from a few outbreaks which were quickly controlled, due partly to higher preparedness by district brigades.

Unfortunately the Koroit district firebug believed responsible for about a dozen blazes is yet to be apprehended.

A small roadside grass fire near Kirkstall on Tuesday afternoon was not believed to be deliberately lit.

Warrnambool-based CFA officer Henry Barton said considering the south-west was the driest region in Victoria during summer, major fire outbreaks were low.

"We were still kept very busy with the Koroit district incidents, Framlingham forest fire, Branxholme forest fires, power pole fires, a hazmat incident at Allansford, tar spill at Portland and truck fire," he said.

"We were able to pull the fires up pretty quickly."

Mr Barton said CFA volunteers and staff were on a higher-than-usual state of preparedness and had upgraded their skills before the fire season.

District five operations manager Nick Brown urged people to remain vigilant and be extremely careful when burning off.

"There is still potential for hot weather and strong winds in the coming week," he said.

"Residents should be aware of daily fire danger ratings and know which fire ban district they are in, particularly if they are travelling."

Anyone planning a burn-off is urged to notify their local brigade beforehand.

urn:contentItem:5P2X-9951-JBJ7-N3W9-00000-00Return of 'big dry' points to active, early fire season2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisReturn of 'big dry' points to active, early fire seasonPeter Hannam

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up.

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up, heightening concerns the coming fire season will be an early and active one.

Fire authorities won't formally release predictions for spring and summer until September. Wet periods in autumn, though, curbed hazard-reduction burning to half the year-earlier totals in NSW and curtailed it in Victoria.

"The next four to six weeks are going to be very important," said Ben Shepherd, an inspector and head of media at the NSW Rural Fire Service.

"Many of the agencies are looking for that opportunity to get out there and start those [hazard-reduction] burns again in earnest" before conditions turn too windy and warm, he said.

Authorities stress a significant rain event could yet push fire risks for the coming season back towards more typical levels but note that there is little sign of such a development.

High-pressure systems have dominated southern Australia, nudging rain-bearing systems south of the continent.

Saturday offered a clear illustration of the set-up. The bureau predicted almost the entire mainland of Australia would be dry. (See chart below.)

The skies have been clear with an unusually wide diurnal temperature range over many regions. Nights were marked by heavy frosts or cold making way for milder than average days.

Big dry

Barring some unexpected instability, July will join last month as among Australia's driest.

Nationally, last month was the second-driest June since standard data began in 1910 with rainfall barely a third of average, the Bureau of Meteorology said.

Victoria had its driest June, NSW was the driest in 15 years and the Murray Darling Basin posted its lowest rainfall totals since 1986.

"It very much seems to be centring on the border between Victoria and NSW," Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre, said of the rainfall deficits.

Winter-to-date rainfall levels have been "very much below average" for most of southern Australia, bureau data shows. (See chart below).

'Back foot'

Fire authorities are keen to take advantage of the cool and dry conditions to ramp up controlled burns before windy and warmer days make such activities more risky.

Cyclone Debbie's aftermath brought heavy rain to much of the east coast in April, reducing opportunities for hazard-reduction burning. "That really put us on the back foot," Mr Shepherd said.

In a typical year about 56 per cent of controlled burns in NSW are conducted in autumn and 23 per cent in spring.

During autumn, the RFS treated 93,116 hectares to protect 23,171 properties. By area, the tally was less than half the previous autumn's 191,684 hectares involving 27,867 properties.

Forest Fire Management Victoria places less emphasis on the size of area burnt in its hazard-reduction program than the risk. During the year to June 2017, FFMVic crews conducted 351 burns over 113,172 hectares statewide.

"The wet winter and spring conditions proved difficult, however our prioritisation of burns based on risk has resulted in the statewide risk being maintained at 2015-16 levels," said Stephanie Rotarangi, the agency's chief fire officer.

Longer-term trends

The key influence behind this year's relatively dry winter is far to the south. A positive phase in the so-called Southern Annular Mode marks a poleward contraction of the westerly winds belt towards Antarctica.

As the bureau notes, such a phase marked the Millennium drought during the "big dry" from 1997-2010. High-pressure systems that would normally sit further north track across more southerly parts of Australia blocking rain-bearing cold fronts.

In June, average mean sea level pressure readings were at record highs for many parts of southern Australia, including all but one site in South Australia and all but three in Victoria.

As the bureau noted: "Mean sea level pressure over southern Australia has been increasing in winter over recent decades. This pattern is consistent with future climate change projections for the Australian region."

Dr Thornton of the Hazards CRC said that along with trends towards drier winters for southern Australia, warmer-than-average temperatures during July to September are also the new norm.

"It's almost locked in to have above-average temperatures from climate change," he said.

The bureau will update its three-month outlook this coming week. At its most recent projection, the agency said odds were strongly pointing to a drier-than-usual July to September for much of the south of the country. (See chart below.)

urn:contentItem:4PRY-D9R0-TXX1-V134-00000-00A Spaniard in the works2007-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisPg. 2A Spaniard in the works

Spanish forester Javier Martin Moreno Mejias

PERTH and Spain may share the mediterranean climate, but that doesn t help when trying to get rid of 40 kangaroo ticks in your jeans.

This is just one of many experiences Spanish forester Javier Martin Moreno Mejias will take back to his homeland after his stint at the Wanneroo Department of Environment and Conservation office.

He has been working as a seasonal firefighter to gain experience in wildfire control in maritime pine (pinus pinaster) plantations.

Having recently finished six years training as a forest engineer in Spain, Mr Mejias is in Australia to learn more about forest fire control and improve his English.

I wanted to learn English and Australians were the friendliest English-speaking people I met in Europe, he said.

DEC staff have also had the opportunity to learn from Mr Mejias visit.

He shared his experience of working for the Spanish National Research Institute of Agriculture and Forestry in forest health and fire laboratory and his role as a specialist in silviculture and fire management at the Polytechnical University of Madrid.

Swan Coastal District Sustainable Forest Management Coordinator Owen Donovan said Mr Mejias fitted in well with the workforce, helping with forest inventory and dieback surveys.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R28D-00000-00CHINA BLAZE OUT OF CONTROL DESPITE 50,000 FIREFIGHTERS1987-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 11CHINA BLAZE OUT OF CONTROL DESPITE 50,000 FIREFIGHTERSMARK O'NEILL Source: Reuter, The Guardian

BEIJING, Thursday: A deadly forest fire that has defied massive firefighting efforts for 15 days has reached the Soviet border and threatens China's northernmost town, the Forestry Ministry said today.

A Ministry official, Ms Shen Wandi, said Communist China's worst forest fire, which has killed 200 people and injured at least 221 others, has largely been controlled on its eastern front.

But she said the situation to the west "is not optimistic at all".

She said the flames had extended to the Heilongjiang (Amur) River dividing China from the Soviet Union and were advancing on Mohe, a village on the river 1,575 kilometres north-east of Beijing and known as China's northernmost community.

She said a fire break had been built to protect the village.

Nearly 50,000 people were now fighting the blaze, the official press said today.

A Chinese reporter who travelled to the hardest hit area has described a countryside of charred houses and trees.

The reporter, from the China News Service, quoted horrified survivors describing the panic and chaos when fireballs swept into a town, destroying it in 20 minutes.

"Smoke was so thick you could not see five metres ahead and trucks loaded with refugees fought with each other on the road, causing many casualties,"the journalist said.

A Canadian forest fire expert, Mr Jack Minor, told reporters in Beijing: "They are facing something that's almost impossible to control. I've never encountered a fire that size."

The fire, which has been blazing in the north-east province of Heilongjiang for two weeks, has killed more than 200 people and seriously injured 221, according to official estimates. About 50,000 people are homeless.

The People's Daily said fires in one part of the western sector had been controlled on Tuesday but had flared again that night and were moving west"like a huge dragon" in a line 75 kilometres long.

Timber reserves are extremely rich in the area and in the autonomous Inner Mongolia region which borders Heilongjiang.

The paper said the situation was extremely dangerous because communications were bad and firefighting capacity was weak.

It said the fire in the eastern sector had been largely controlled, thanks to a 100-metre-wide fire ditch dug by earth-moving vehicles.

The China Daily said an extra 4,650 soldiers and forest police were being rushed to the disaster area from other parts of China to join the 44,400 already there.

It said eight hospitals had been set up in the area and four medical teams had been sent in to ensure clean food for the firefighters and to prevent epidemics.

The New China News Agency said people in the area were eating pre-cooked food, rather than using fire to cook.

It said donations for fire victims had been received from Hong Kong businessmen and Red Cross societies in several countries.

The fire is believed to have been started by an oil leak from a bush-cutting machine.

Forest fires in the Chita region of eastern Siberia had destroyed 200,000 hectares of woodland, Soviet television reported today.

The report said fires were still raging at 50 separate sites despite intensive efforts to control them.

urn:contentItem:5X6K-7HC1-JD34-V3SB-00000-00The fire danger period isn't far away - are you prepared?2019-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisThe fire danger period isn't far away - are you prepared?Alex Ford

Properties need to be prepared now before the fire danger period begins, fire chiefs say.

While conditions look good now, spring growth and shifting weather could lead to another dangerous summer.

This year, the fourth major fire in the Ballarat district ignited in April, much later than expected.

While authorities are putting their plans into action, it will still come down to landholders, especially those with properties near bushland or forests, to do their part and prevent fire risks.

READ MORE: 'We could see a silhouette in the smoke': How CFA crew saved a life

District 15 operations manager Brett Boatman said to expect the fire danger period to be declared close to Ballarat Cup Day, which is about average for the area.

"Where we sit, and my district takes in Hepburn, Moorabool, Golden Plains - most of it - and City of Ballarat, we've had a pretty good winter," he said.

"We've had average to above average rainfall - I'm working on the bogged tractor index, and we've had a lot of bogged tractors out there in paddocks - and that means, for us, we're expecting the fire danger period, which is when we declare restrictions, to be what we'd call average, somewhere around the first part of December or late November."

He noted there were lessons learned from the fires last year, which saw one every month through the summer and into autumn.

"It's really significant, we're not normally that busy, and last year wasn't a super dry year for us, it was all about Gippsland, but we still had the Buninyong fire just before Christmas, the Hepburn-Mannings Road fire at the end of January, the Bunkers Hill fire out in Haddon in mid-March, and in April we had the Mount Clear fire," he explained.

"Overall, we lost two homes and about 35 sheds last summer, communities lost those.

"What we're seeing is we don't need a fire that'll going to burn thousands of hectares and run for many days to do a lot of damage."

He described the Bunkers Hill fire as being like a "tornado in a caravan park".

"(It was) small landholdings, two or five to 10 acres, varying levels of community preparedness, a warm day but not a hot day, but an especially windy day in late summer, and ignition from powerlines," he said.

"It was dangerous, for community and for our people, it was very extreme fire danger and behaviour, it was very erratic."

Based on this, he said landholders should begin to remove long grass and get rid of bonfire piles now.

"People have the burn pile in the paddock, they're ready to have everyone around for a beer and barbecue and burn the pile, then the fire danger period gets declared before they expect it, so we're saying if you've got that pile of things to burn, get it done early," Mr Boatman said.

"I'm saying get it done before Ballarat Show Day (November 9)."

Council inspectors will soon be checking properties for fire-readiness as well, he added.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is also reviewing fuel loads in the district and getting early spring burns done in risky areas - Midlands district manager Jasmine Filmer said project crews were beginning to arrive, and other initiatives, like the fire watchtower program and water point development, were under way.

"For us, it's about making sure that we maximise the opportunities when they're there," she said.

"We've got those couple of burns under our belt, and potentially there'll be another spring burn, but the spring program won't be big, the majority of it will be focused on autumn when we have more stable conditions.

"We haven't formally kicked off the slashing program, that's where people see us out with tractors in the forest, that includes slashing of verges and other tracks through the forested areas, and would also include mowing in areas like Crown land, township blocks, and verges elsewhere.

"The trick is, we don't want to start too early, because then we get more growth and we end up having to redo that as well, so it's a timing run with that stuff."

The Mount Clear fire, which threatened pine plantations close to homes, was a good example of the chain of command working well in an emergency, she added - firefighters from the Hancock plantations and FFMV worked with CFA crews to establish control over the fire quickly.

"It was late in the season - when that was occurring, we had done planned burning in the days prior and we had scheduled planned burns for Trentham the following day," she said.

"That day was warm and windy, but the day following was perfect conditions for a planned burn, so we delivered a planned burn at Trentham in a really high risk environment but in conditions that were very favourable."

The full aerial firefighting fleet will be available, as well as surge capacity and night firebombing crews.

The plantation crews are also ready to roll - Hancock Victoria Plantations maintains a private firefighting team in the summer, which corporate fires manager Ruth Ryan described as a "CFA brigade in its own right".

"There's two tankers and five quick attack utes stationed around the Ballarat area, which respond to fires on and off our land," she said.

"We take on additional crew over the summer, we have a base firefighting capacity of around 20 people during the weekdays, and people on standby over weekends."

The company is working closely with fire authorities on new initiatives, she added, helping to plan ahead for the summer.

"Some of the things we're getting involved in on a more broad scale are using computer modelling to identify risk areas, and we use that to highlight potentially where we might work with FFMV to identify areas where fuel management would have the best effect, especially in protecting our plantations," she said.

The district's CFA brigades - all 61 of them, and their 120 vehicles - will soon begin extra training, focusing on personal safety and situational awareness while out at fires.

"We have a tree hazard awareness training package that all of our people go through before summer," Mr Boatman explained.

"We're also encouraging people to know their procedures around entrapment, if they do get caught in a burnover - there was one in Queensland, and at the Scotsburn fire we had three entrapments that day.

"It's something we do see pop up and we're encouraging all of our members to refresh their entrapment drills so they understand what the procedures are if they're caught in that situation.

"Everyone has a minimum level of training on the fire truck and we're re-emphasising that, so we're expecting that every person who gets on a fire truck and goes to a fire this summer will have done those three things."

That emphasis on safety is being echoed across the state - in a statement, Victorian emergency management commissioner Andrew Crisp said multi-agency briefings had begun to make sure people know the risks and are prepared to respond.

"This includes briefings in Ballarat, Ararat and Horsham, for emergency management personnel," he said.

"We are also focused on the health and safety of our responders and emergency managers, so that they are able to continue to protect and respond to the community in emergencies.

"Each year it is clear that summer is not just about fire alone, it is also about flooding, storms, and other emergencies. Each year we ask the community to also begin their preparedness works, taking action to complete preparations early. This year is no different.

"While emergency management agencies are preparing, it's also important the community understands their own risk and is actively preparing. This is a shared responsibility."

On the ground, the focus is on forested areas and the "interface" between the bush and pastoral land.

"We've had plenty of examples where they might be grass fires but they're having significant impacts, and if that's moving out of or into a forest where we've got homes, then they're really tricky ones to deal with," Ms Filmer said.

Mr Boatman agreed.

"There's a place called Wheatsheaf just east of Daylesford, there's 200-odd landholders on an area of bush that's been subdivided and people live right in the middle of it," he said.

"We've got a very proactive campaign around engaging with that community, and we're also looking, under a policy called Safer Together which we do with FFMV, to help landholders manage their blocks of land out there through burning and other means.

"If you wrap around from Haddon and Smythes Creek, all the way around Smythesdale, Napoleons, the south of Ballarat across to Buninyong and Scotsburn, and across to almost Dunnstown, that area, you think about how much bush and how much interface - then if you go up from Creswick to Smoky Town over towards Newlyn, skip over into the Wombat (Forest), Daylesford, Trentham, Blackwood, there's lots of places where there's interface.

"That's why preparation is key."

There are plenty of resources on the CFA website for landowners, he added, and no excuses for not checking it out now.

"I'm a landowner on the outskirts of Ballarat, I've got 10 acres and I know what it all looks like - the conversation and thinking needs to start now," he said.

"Within communities, landowners, families, neighbours, they all need to start thinking about 'what can I start to do now to minimise my risk?'"

urn:contentItem:5535-B3C1-JD3N-52CN-00000-00$600m climate bonanza Cash heads overseas2012-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2$600m climate bonanza Cash heads overseasSteve Lewis

AUSTRALIA'S foreign aid program will spend $600 million on climate change programs in Third World countries.

Pacific, Caribbean and African countries will share millions of dollars to help tackle climate change while environmental advisers will be paid $200,000 or more to help some of the world's poorest countries.

Another $3 million will be spent developing five-star green energy ratings for fridges, airconditioners and other household appliances in the Pacific as AusAID searches for ways to spend its growing budget.

Millions of dollars will be spent to retrofit houses in poor African communities, while $15 million will be pumped into helping villagers along the Mekong Delta in Vietnam.

The Opposition last night called on Prime Minister Julia Gillard to immediately suspend the ``wasteful spending'' on climate change.

The $600 million spend on climate change comes as the rapidly growing aid program -- managed by AusAID -- has reached a staggering $13.3 billion in managed contracts, according to documents published this week.

More than 6000 separate contracts are being managed by AusAID, with 4000 contracts negotiated in just one year, 2010-11.

Documents show about $3 million is being spent to ``build a group of Pacific leaders'' with a greater understanding of climate change, while $20 million will be spent to help East Timor better understand changing weather patterns.

Senior government ministers keen to slow the large sums being channelled into foreign aid are likely to use Kevin Rudd's demise as foreign affairs minister to argue for budget reductions.

Coalition foreign affairs spokeswoman Julie Bishop labelled the climate change spending ``an outrageous abuse of Australian foreign aid''.

``I call on the Prime Minister to immediately suspend this expenditure on programs that will have zero impact on global emissions,'' she said.

WARMING UP FOR A BIG SPEND

$100m Climate change deal with Indonesia including "online forest fire monitoring system" and teaching sustainable farming in schools

$20m Research through "Pacific climate change science program"

$3m To develop a group of Pacific "leaders" who can better understand climate change

$3m To help Pacific nations introduce five-star "green energy" ratings for fridges, airconditioners and lights

Source: AusAID, Comm Govt

urn:contentItem:5BM1-0H01-JD3N-518Y-00000-00Glacial trio cause global warming2014-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:58ZLexisNexisHITPg. 45Glacial trio cause global warmingMIKEY CAHILL MUSIC WRITER

ROCK CITY Sydney label Future Classic are untouchable right now. Along with Flume, Jagwar Ma, Flight Facilities, Chet Faker and Wave Racer they have a recent addition to their roster: Sydney's ghetto-ambient, atmos-step trio Seekae.

The first single, Another, from their third album due mid-late 2014 has notched 510,000 plays on their Soundcloud page. That's strong word of mouse!

Another is four minutes of kissed-off, glacier-paced, electronic emancipation riding on Alex Cameron's inner monologue confessed out loud: "I want another girl, I thought that you should know." "The album's working title is The Worry," says George Nicholas, one of the programming princes in the group. "We use tense, dissonant chords to create that 'anxiety sound', it's just how it turned out." It's working for you, Gorgeous George.

Before that though, fans and fans-to-be can snap up a limited edition 3LP super-deluxe vinyl re-release of the super-tight +DOME and The Sound Of Trees Falling On People this Monday. With Easter eggs.

"We've made some locked grooves. I did an ambient one of Forest Fire and we have another one of 3 from +Dome. It's one and a half seconds looped that lock the needle endlessly at the end of the record." In the next month, the boys play Golden Plains, then Austin for SXSW showcases and shows across UK/Europe.

Sadly, Seekae have the 4.10pm slot on the Sunday while Cut/Copy are scheduled to play 12.40am Monday morning. Surely they can be swapped, around, Nephew Woody?

"We need to start a Get Up campaign," agrees Nicholas.

Golden Plains, Meredith. March 8-10. goldenplains.net NORWEGIAN WOULD BulgarianNorwegian cabaret pop hero Mikhael Paskalev is a beautiful bitsa. The man who came number 75 in the Triple Hottest 100 last year with I Spy posits "Australians seem to understand me." Paskalev is very promosexual and here next Friday.

"Silverchair were my favourite band growing up and Home and Away was always on [TV], I'd glance at the chicks' sunbleached hair," he quips.
